Headline: Barron's(2/12) Market Watch: A Sampling Of Advisory Opinion
Story: (From BARRON'S)     Edited By Anita Peltonen     Market Watch     Win Some, Lose Some     Currency View by Brown Brothers Harriman   140 Broadway, New York, N.Y. 10005     Feb. 5-7: While manufacturing continues to struggle to pick up, the larger part of the economy, the services sector, remains firm. The data reinforce the view that the U.S. economy is growing at a moderate pace, and are modestly dollar supportive.   U.S. weekly [Mortgage Bankers Association] mortgage applications slipped 0.2%, after a 3.2% rise the previous week. The U.S. reported fourth-quarter 2006 [productivity rose at a stronger-than-expected 3% annual pace in 4Q06; unit-labor costs fell.]   -- Nick Bennebroek, Meg Browne, Marc Chandler     Bush Bites Into Health-Care Spending     Washington Research by Prudential Equity   1 New York Plaza, New York, N.Y. 10292     Feb. 6.: President Bush's '08 budget proposal . . . would significantly cut provider-payments in the Medicare program. Of the $65.6 billion in proposed spending reductions, hardest hit would be hospitals, then other Part A services like skilled-nursing facilities and home health. The proposal again recommends reducing rental periods for [some medical] equipment, while also addressing the issue of paying providers differently for providing similar post acute-care services.   While we expect Democrats to resist most of the Medicare proposals, in our view, they will not be able to avoid addressing them, since they have their own health-care priorities that will need to be funded. When the debate begins on how and where to cut spending, we believe [Medicare Advantage] plans, hospitals, and [skilled-nursing facilities] face the most risk.   -- Kim Monk     A Rowdy Russell     Update Hotline   by U.S. Investment Report   65 Chapel Road, New Hope, Pa. 18938     Feb. 6: The Standard & Poor's 500 and Dow Industrials continue to edge to new highs, basking in a mainly upbeat glow of [recent] Federal Reserve comments. The Nasdaq sector is not too far from the peak of its late January burst. Best performer of all right now is the small-cap Russell 2000, which is up 2.5% year to date versus 2% for the S&P, 1.6% for the Dow and 2.3% for Nasdaq.   -- Stephen Quickel     Fret-Fest Ignores Robust Market     Goldilocks, Davos and the Wall of Worry   by ING Investment Weekly   10 State House Sq., Hartford, Conn. 06103     Feb. 5: At the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, the world's most worried publicity seekers gathered with no joy in late January to fret together over the woeful state of the world. Bond-market participants have a . . . reputation of frowning on good news, but these Davos types are champion frowners . . . Comments about the scale of financial derivatives and whether markets are pricing risks properly echoed off the Alps, while the markets continued to chug along.   While not trying to minimize significant economic challenges, financial markets do have a pretty good nose for risk and threats. There is a disconnect somewhere.   The view here: Fed vigilance on inflation is justified. That focus, plus global competition, continued application of technology, and productivity gains will join forces to keep a lid on it. In terms of other economic threats, we are reminded of how contained recent market crises have been:   The blowup of large hedge-fund Ama-ranth . . . A decade earlier, the death of much smaller LTCM led to a Fed ease.   The crash of GM and Ford, with wrenching job losses, led not to recession but to GM being best '06 performer in Dow 30.   A springtime meltdown in emerging markets, triggered by carry-trade-threatening rate rise in Japan, settled down rapidly.   Nationalization in Venezuela/tremors from Ecuador and Bolivia, didn't result in 90s-type contagion . . .   A misstep in Thailand's economic policy was quickly reversed . . .   The U.S. shrugged off $77 oil and awaited the thud as housing hit the floor . . . the subprime market is the likely candidate for the next financial accident. Some will lose houses . . . [but] tighter monetary policies and an inverted yield curve have not led to feared recession or financial crisis. Altogether, Goldilocks would be pleased.   -- Richard Kilbride     Gold's Still Good     Continue to Like Gold: 2006 Annual Letter   by Greenfield Seitz Capital Management   2001 Ross Ave., Dallas, Texas 75201     Jan. 31: Gold has increased from $280 in 2002 to finish 2006 at a price of $638 an ounce . . . We are attracted to gold's historical hedge against inflation, a weakening U.S. dollar, and a declining stock market. We believe gold is in a secular bull market after . . . declining prices from 1980-2001. . . . World gold production has declined since 2000, despite a more than 100% increase in the price of gold. However, there is no assurance gold will continue to rise in value.   -- Stuart Greenfield     Homebuilders Looking Up     Momentum Strategies Report   by Clif Droke Publishing Concepts   P.O. Box 3401, Topsail Beach, N.C. 28445     Feb. 5: The leading indicators, which almost no one looks at these days, are screaming "Improvement is coming!" for the physical real-estate sector, not only in the way the REITs are consistently making all-time highs but also in the improvement among the homebuilders. I'd like to point out again that the Philly Housing Sector Index made an all-time high on Feb. 2, and since bottoming in July '06 has established a steady upward trend that has seen it retrace most of its 2006 losses.   Leading-indicator stock . . . Home Depot, a Dow 30 component, has also performed well and looks to have higher to go in its six-month-old recovery. Also, the Dow Jones U.S. Building Materials and Fixtures Index is in a remarkable bull market since bottoming last July, and has now completely retraced its bear market from last year, recently making a 52-week high. The turnaround in the building-materials index has been among the most impressive turnarounds among industry groups in the past year.   -- Clif Droke   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 00:06 ET (05:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/12) The Electronic Investor: Tax Software For Serious Investors
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Theresa W. Carey   Frequent traders who do their own taxes are either control freaks (my category) or very comfortable with the ins and outs of tax accounting. Crazy is another possibility. In any case, do-it-yourselfers of all types need tax software -- either packaged or online.   Any tax program should be able to deal with income and deductions, but the serious investor needs to compile an accurate Schedule D, covering all transactions. There's no shortage of software alternatives. Sorting through them -- particularly the jumble you see in stores -- is the problem.   The two big players are TurboTax, from Intuit, and TaxCut, from H&R Block. Both offer long lists of software, plus a menu of online tax-prep choices, which you access via your Web browser.   We looked at TurboTax's Premier Investments ($74.95) and TaxCut's Premium Federal+State+e-file ($59.95). We also evaluated online site CompleteTax (www.completetax.com), published by CCH, a tax-preparation outfit.   One big benefit of TurboTax is its link to financial-service providers, letting you import your investment data -- if your broker is on its list. Fidelity, Schwab and E*Trade transactions can be accessed this way, but customers of brokerages devoted to active traders, such as Schwab's CyberTrader, TradeStation and Interactive Brokers, will have to enter data manually or find some other way to fetch it. TurboTax's import list hasn't caught up with rapid industry consolidation, either -- TD Ameritrade, for instance, isn't listed, though its component parts, Ameritrade and TD Waterhouse, are.   TurboTax also let me import a W-2 from a large employer; this one was prepared by the employer-sponsored payroll site of Fidelity (a separate unit of the mutual-fund giant). If your employer's payroll software cooperates with TurboTax, the form can be pulled in easily if you have a user-ID and password. Be sure to check the imported figures against the W-2 mailed to you. TaxCut users have to enter their W-2s manually.   BasisPro is a new twist in TurboTax this year. It allows you to figure out the historical cost basis of an investment, which is especially helpful if you've sold a long-time stock or mutual-fund holding. For example, if you sold 600 shares of Hewlett-Packard (ticker: HPQ) stock last year that you purchased in 1996, your cost could be attributed to some old HP (HWP) shares that have split twice, or legacy stock from HP acquisitions like Compaq. BasisPro looks all that up for you and figures out your cost basis.   The BasisPro feature requires a connection to the Web, and unfortunately makes you re-enter the information you just typed into TurboTax. Perhaps a future version will eliminate the extra keystrokes. Even so, it's a welcome feature.   TaxCut has vastly improved its interview process, now focusing on data flow rather than the income tax form itself, making it much easier to use. Still, it lacks the huge number of automatic imports that TurboTax has. However, if you use Microsoft Money or Intuit's Quicken, or any other program that can create Tax Exchange Format (.txf) files, you can still grab the appropriate transactions.   TaxCut includes one federal and state e-file per package; if you file multiple returns from one copy you will pay another $15.95 for additional e-files. We like TaxCut's advice on the tax ramifications of life changes like marriage or retirement.   CompleteTax has a simple, clean interface, and the price ($25.95 for a federal return, $12.95 for each state return) includes e-filing. Users of GainsKeeper, to which many online brokers link customers for gain/loss reporting, are the most likely to benefit from this program. CompleteTax can only import data from Gains-Keeper files; everything else has to be entered manually.   One solution for traders with reams of taxable transactions is TradeLog (http:// www.armencomp.com/tradelog), published by Armen Computing. We like TradeLog for active stock and options traders. It does a much better job of tracking options transactions than Quicken or Money, and it's a good tool for short-sellers. TradeLog can also help you track futures transactions, which aren't specifically addressed in other programs.   TradeLog offers five versions, keyed to transaction volume. TradeLog 200, which covers up to 200 trades, is $69. The top-of-the-line GTT TradeLog, which handles unlimited transactions and is aimed at those needing mark-to-market accounting, is $349. GTT TradeLog is also supported by Green Trader Tax (www.greentradertax.com), which provides tax advice for frequent traders.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 00:04 ET (05:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Keith S. Hynes to Retire as Chief Financial Officer of Max Re Capital Ltd., Joe Roberts Named as His Successor
Story: HAMILTON, Bermuda--(BUSINESS WIRE)--February 10, 2007--   Max Re Capital Ltd. (NASDAQ: MXRE; BSX: MXRE BH) today announced that Keith S. Hynes, the Company's Chief Financial Officer, has indicated his intention to retire, effective April 1, 2007.     On that date, Mr. Hynes, who is currently one of the longest-serving insurance company CFOs in Bermuda, will be succeeded by Joe Roberts. Mr. Roberts, currently Senior Vice President and Controller, will be promoted to Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.     W. Marston Becker, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Max Re Capital, said: "On behalf of all of us at Max Re, I want to thank Keith for his loyal and capable service to the Company, and to congratulate Joe on his well-deserved promotion. I also want to express my appreciation to Keith for his key role in helping us build a strong, seasoned financial management team, thereby ensuring a smooth and seamless transition."     Mr. Roberts joined Max Re Capital in May 2002 as Controller. Since that time, he has led the Company's Sarbanes-Oxley compliance initiatives and its financial reporting process. Prior to joining Max Re, he was a vice president for Overseas Partners Re Ltd. From 1994 to 2001, Mr. Roberts worked with KPMG, most recently as a senior manager, where he specialized in providing assurance-based services to the financial services sector. From 1987 to 1994, Mr. Roberts worked in public accounting in London, primarily with Moore Stephens. He is a member of the Institute of Chartered Accountants in England and Wales.     Max Re Capital Ltd., through its principal operating subsidiaries, Max Re Ltd., Max Insurance Europe Limited and Max Re Europe Limited, provides insurance and reinsurance products to corporations, public entities, property and casualty insurers and life and health insurers.     This release includes statements about future expectations, plans and prospects of the Company that constitute forward-looking statements for purposes of the safe harbor provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Such forward-looking statements are subject to certain risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those suggested by such statements, including the risk that the SEC's view of the conclusions reached by the Audit and Risk Management Committee of the Company's Board of Directors in connection with the internal review of three finite risk retrocessional contracts written in 2001 and 2003, which caused the Company to restate its audited financial statements for the years ended December 31, 2005, 2004, 2003, 2002 and 2001 and unaudited financial statements for the periods ended March 31, 2006 and June 30, 2006, may differ, perhaps materially, and result in material changes to information contained in the Company's past SEC filings, including financial statements and financial information. For further information regarding cautionary statements and factors affecting future results, please refer to the Company's Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q/A for the period ended September 30, 2006 and other documents filed by the Company with the SEC. The Company undertakes no obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statement whether as a result of new information, future developments or otherwise.        CONTACT: Max Re Capital Ltd.               N. James Tees, 1-441-296-8800               Executive Vice President               jimt@maxre.bm               or               Kekst and Company               Roy Winnick, 1-212-521-4842               roy-winnick@kekst.com        SOURCE: Max Re Capital Ltd.  Copyright Business Wire 2007     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 08:10 ET (13:10 GMT)

Headline: Delphi Chmn Vows To Preserve Commitment To Workers -Report
Story: NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--Delphi Corp. (DPH) Chairman Steve Miller said Friday that preserving established commitments to its workers is a top priority in the auto supplier's Chapter 11 bankruptcy restructuring, even as the company negotiates for lower labor costs that could set Detroit's struggling auto industry on a new, healthier trajectory, the Detroit Free Press reported on its Web site.   "It's been my objective to preserve the pension entitlements," Miller said Friday during a luncheon forum of the Jewish Federation of Metropolitan Detroit in Birmingham. But he said Delphi and the Detroit automakers can't continue to make generous promises to future workers if they plan to survive, the report said.   Miller delivered his remarks as Detroit's automakers prepare for contract negotiations with the UAW and Delphi works on a tight deadline to reach a new labor agreement with its unions and former owner General Motors Corp. (GM) to protect a $3.4-billion investment by private equity investors in the supplier's restructuring. Delphi already missed the investors' initial Jan. 31 deadline to reach a labor agreement and is now working on a Feb. 28 deadline.   "I believe we will find solutions we can all live with," Miller said of the Delphi talks, according to the report. "People on all sides of the Delphi negotiations are focused on providing for the "honest, loyal, hard-working people who took a job at GM or Delphi long ago and played by the rules," Miller said.   "But I will not shy away from facing up to the harsh realities of our situation," he said. The harsh reality, Miller described, is one in which nonunion domestic rivals and foreign companies can charge less for the same components because they offer lower wages and long-term benefits, the report said.   To compete against those rivals, Miller said, Delphi and the Detroit automakers need the freedom to offer lower, more competitive wage and benefits packages, the report added.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 04:08 ET (09:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/12) The EOP Buyout: A Big Gamble For Private Equity
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Andrew Bary   The $39 billion buyout of Equity Office Properties brings together in a single transaction some powerful financial trends, including the mania for commercial real estate, the strength of private-equity firms and the extraordinary liquidity in the debt markets.   It represents a bold bet by Blackstone Group, which won a bidding contest for Equity Office Properties (ticker: EOP), that it can get lofty prices for buildings that it plans to sell and much higher rents forthe properties that it intends to keep.   Blackstone Group, one of the leading private-equity operators, didn't leave much margin for error after it was forced to increase its all-cash bid to $55.50 a share from the $48.50 that it initially agreed to in November. The price bump came after a group led by Vornado Realty Trust made a counter-offer.   Blackstone plans to pay for the Equity Office Properties with a staggering $31 billion of debt, a $3.5 billion bridge loan and $3.65 billion of equity from its funds, according to recent EOP filings. Even after Friday's sale of eight EOP Manhattan buildings for $7 billion, Blackstone could be sitting with equity equal to an aggressive 11% of assets, versus the more comfortable 50% that real-estate investment trusts typically maintain.   The talk on Wall Street is that Blackstone wants to liquidate in short order a good portion of the EOP portfolio. The prices it receives will help determine whether EOP amounts to another coup for private equity or a reprise of the debacle that followed the high-profile RJR Nabisco buyout in the 1980s.   Blackstone's ability to defeat Vornado is a testament to huge institutional appetite for debt, because Blackstone brought little to the transaction beside a sliver of equity, while Vornado offered EOP holders equity in one of the largest real-estate investment trusts.   The EOP drama featured some outsized actors, including Steve Schwarzman, the chairman and CEO of Blackstone; Steve Roth, the chief executive of Vornado (VNO); and Sam Zell, the chairman and founder of EOP.   Now a billionaire, Schwarzman is perhaps the leading light in the world of private equity and one of the top financial people in New York, where Schwarzman soon plans to celebrate his 60th birthday with a lavish party for 1,500 people. Schwarzman lives in a gigantic apartment in the most exclusive building on Park Avenue -- an apartment once owned by a titan of another era, John D. Rockefeller Jr.   There has been less attention on the financial details of the EOP deal. Blackstone's challenge is that the interest costs on the debt it is incurring to buy EOP may exceed the operating income from EOP's properties, some 585 buildings with nearly 100 million square feet of rentable space. Blackstone declined to comment.   With the Manhattan properties sold for $7 billion, or a hefty $1,100 per square foot, Blackstone could be left with $1.6 billion in annualized operating income from the remaining buildings. The interest costs on the remaining debt could total $2 billion annually at an estimated, possibly conservative cost of 7%. The interest expense, therefore, could exceed the annual operating income. Blackstone is apt to structure the debt so that it doesn't have to pay current interest on all the debt, giving it some breathing room. But it leaves the firm vulnerable to any unexpected weakness in the commercial property market.   Blackstone is effectively getting a 5% current yield, or "cap rate," on the EOP portfolio, considerably below its own funding costs. Current record-low yields on commercial real estate leave leveraged buyers vulnerable to a rise in short rates -- an event that may not be so unlikely given hawkish comments Friday by two Federal Reserve officials that cooled the boiling market for REIT shares.   The office market has been improving in much of the country, particularly in midtown Manhattan, where prime space now rents for $150 a square foot annually, four to five times the rate in many regional markets. EOP's biggest markets outside New York are Boston, Chicago and San Francisco. While office rents now are headed up, it's worth remembering that they went down after the Internet bubble burst in 2000.   Blackstone won't benefit immediately from higher rents because only about 11% of the EOP leases expire this year and another 12% in 2008. In its third-quarter 10-Q filing, EOP said that rates on new 2006 leases actually were running about 10% below those on expiring leases -- a trend Blackstone will need to reverse to justify the price it paid. For leases that began in the September quarter, EOP was averaging $29 a square foot.   The high leverage on the EOP portfolio cuts both ways. If Blackstone can sell the properties for 10% more than it paid for them, that would translate into about $4 billion in profits, or a doubling of its $3.6 billion initial equity investment. If it ultimately gets $35 billion for the portfolio, the Blackstone equity could be wiped out.   The loser in the EOP battle, Vornado CEO Steve Roth, is a sharp operator with a value bent. He assembled an impressive office portfolio in the country's two hottest markets, Midtown Manhattan and Washington. Roth's unwillingness to bet his company and top Blackstone showed restraint that could be rewarded.   Zell, meanwhile, personally reaped about $900 million on the sale and cemented his reputation as a shrewd deal maker. He orchestrated the sale of a property portfolio assembled over three decades at what could be the top of the market. Blackstone has a reputation for real-estate smarts but Zell may be the one who was right.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 00:07 ET (05:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UK PRESS: Sanofi Talks On Merger Founder Over Price
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)-- Sanofi-Aventis (SNY) has called off talks with Bristol-Myers Squibb over a deal to create the world's biggest pharmaceutical group because of disagreements over price and legal disputes surrounding the top-selling drug, The Times reports Saturday without citing its sources.   The paper writes an acquisition would have created a drugs giant with a market value of $175 billion and revenue of $56 billion, outstripping the market leader Pfizer (PFE).   It is understood that Sanofi wasn't comfortable with the valuation of Bristol-Myers with a share price of around $28, the paper writes.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.thetimes.co.uk   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9320   (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 07:43 ET (12:43 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UK PRESS: Turkey In Shops Could Be Withdrawn
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--The British Food Standards Agency is considering the withdrawal of processed turkeys from shops across the U.K. after it emerged that Bernard Matthews, the food company, may have continued processing meat infected with the H5N1 bird flu virus over the past week, the Financial Times reports Saturday, citing the agency.   While stressing there was virtually no risk to public health from eating infected but properly cooked meat, the agency said Friday it wasn't ruling out that turkeys processed by Bernard Matthews carried the virus, writes the paper. If so, the paper reports the agency would act because it is illegal to sell infected meat.   Bernard Matthews wouldn't respond to detailed questions on the infection, the paper adds.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.ft.com   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9320     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 06:14 ET (11:14 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/12) Barron's Online: Temporary Ailments
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Johanna Bennett   Beleaguered generic-drug giant Teva Pharmaceutical Industries should regain its health. The company's American depositary receipts fell 28% last year, even though profits skyrocketed by an estimated 47%. Reason: Teva's top-selling drugs face new competition, threatening earnings. In addition, Teva's decision to replace retiring CEO Israel Makov with an industry outsider has raised eyebrows.   Yet with its price-earnings multiple near a five-year low and profitsexpectedto climb in 2008, Teva looks compelling. "For the highest reward, you have to be willing to buy Teva in 2007, when earnings are likely to fall from last year's high levels," says Peter Schofield, managing director of Knott Capital, an Exton, Pa., investment firm. "But once the market looks ahead to 2008, it will start to reward Teva." By then, Teva could have launched 80 new generic drugs in the U.S. Meanwhile, it's focusing on faster-growing markets in Latin America and Europe.   Sales of Copaxone, Teva's multiple sclerosis drug, and other branded medications, which now account for 14% of company sales, are also rising, boosting margins. And last year's $7.6 billion acquisition of rival Ivax could significantly generate economies of scale. "Teva has exposure outside the U.S. and a plausible cost-cutting story," says Ronny Gal, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein. "There are very logical reasons why the company will do better in 2008."   Founded in 1901, Teva, whose ADRs trade on Nasdaq under the ticker symbol TEVA, is the largest player in the $60 billion global market for generics, cheaper copycats of branded drugs, beating chief rival Novartis (NVS).   Like its competitors, Teva cashed in on the rash of branded drugs whose patents expired in the past few years. Generic-drug sales generated about 76% of last year's estimated $8.4 billion in revenue, says Randall Stanicky, a Goldman Sachs analyst. Teva fills about one of every four generic prescriptions in the U.S., the world's largest prescription-drug market.   But in 2007, Teva's revenue should climb just 6%, and profits could fall 8%, to $2.15 a share, according to Thomson Financial. Meanwhile, Makov, 67, is retiring. His successor is Shlomo Yanai, 55, a retired Israeli major general who formerly was the boss of a maker of generic agrochemicals. "Given our wealth of talent, the company felt able to select a leader from outside the industry for his leadership skills," says Kevin Mannix, a Teva spokesman, in an e-mail to Barron's Online.   Teva's revenue could rise about 12% in 2008, to $9.9 billion, boosting profits 17%, says Goldman's Stanicky. Teva has 144 applications before the Food and Drug Administration for new drugs targeting $87 billion in branded sales. Those products could generate $3 billion in incremental revenue, says Knott Capital. By 2008, Teva's generics could deliver $7.1 billion in revenue, Stanicky says. And Teva's branded-drug sales, led by Copaxone, are far more profitable and should climb 50% by 2008 to $1.8 billion, generating 19% of Teva's top line.   Still, Teva's ADRs, recently around 35, look enticing. At 16.2 times projected profit over the next 12 months, they change hands at a discount to the broad market and in line with the drug maker's projected 16% annual long-term earnings growth. A bet on Teva could be the Rx for healthy gains, starting in 2008.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 00:10 ET (05:10 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/12) The Big Question For Big Oil: Where To Invest?
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Sandra Ward   Interview With Art Smith   Chairman and chief executive, John S. Herold     There are few who come to the energy sector with such complete knowledge of the industry's past, present and likely future than Art Smith, head of John S. Herold, the Norwalk, Conn.-based energy research firm. Armed with a battery of analysts, a proprietary database of 400 publicly held oil companies and more than 30 years' experience in the industry, Smith and his advice are considered byhis clients to be the sine qua non of their decision making. He's also begun to take his own advice and has started providing investment-advisory services through Herold in the past year. Smith recently shared with us where he thinks the money will be made in 2007.     Barron's: We'd all be better off had we invested in your stock picks last year. What are you recommending this year?   Smith: I did a Webcast a few weeks ago called the "Petroleum Exploration Paradox." According to our president, we are addicted to oil, but apparently we don't want to explore for it anymore. All of the data we collect show the industry's capital investment in the upstream -- for exploration, anyway -- has been declining substantially from where it was five and 10 years ago. It amounts to 15 cents on the dollar when it used to be 30 cents on the dollar.   Basically, the exploration model hasn't been working, so no one is funding it. The big oil companies have determined the best thing they can do is continue to buy in their own stock and pay dividends.     Q: This is a theme that has been going on for a while.   A: It has really showed up since the bull market in energy got going in 2001. Companies have become complacent with what they are doing and, the fact is, other than ExxonMobil or BP or Royal Dutch Shell, the exploration and production companies have very few success stories to talk about.   The world has shrunk insofar as there are fewer countries companies can expect to sign exploration agreements with and hope to find something and make money on. Angola comes to mind and Equatorial Guinea. If you are successful in places such as Venezuela, Colombia and Nigeria, you run a pretty great risk of having it taken away from you.     Q: How does this theme factor into your overall outlook for this year?   A: Oil-industry profitability peaked in the June quarter last year. Cash flow and earnings are robust, but margins are under severe pressure because oil-service costs have made a major leap upward and haven't come down very much. Finally, the industry has awakened to the fact that the real problem is not profitability but reinvestment and economic value-added.   Barron's identified ConocoPhillips as the most undervalued large-cap stock, and then the company came under pressure when they announced they had a very poor year with upstream exploration and had replaced only 13% of their reserves with the drill bit. Had they not bought Burlington Resources, it would really have been ugly. They had a terrible year with reserve replacement.     Q: So what are the consequences of this?   A: Our bottom line on this exploration paradox is that it will cause the large companies to review all the major players in the world, and those that have undeveloped reserves of significant magnitude but require capital will be the targets. Major oil companies have become bankers, rather than risk-takers.     Q: The energy sector got off to a rocky start this year. What should we make of that?   A: It was a very interesting start to the year for all of us in the energy sector. It was so warm the first week or two of January that the Nymex traders came back from their vacations and decided to sell the sector off like there was no tomorrow. I don't think I've seen a correction quite as swift and ugly as that one. The sector sold off between 10% and 15% in less than 10 trading days. There were no survivors.   Then lo and behold, Old Man Winter showed up and so-called OPEC solidarity showed up as well as the group threatened to reduce production by another 500,000 barrels a day on top of the 1.2 million barrels a day they announced last fall. The IEA [International Energy Association] is actually worried they will overdo it. Right now, I'm in the camp that says we could easily have $80 oil this year. The only other person in that camp is Ed Morse, Lehman Brothers' chief energy economist.   I am amazed at how the market is influenced by very modest changes in estimates of natural gas inventories or estimated demand. We are talking about 85 million barrels a day of oil being consumed and the market will sell off on a change in estimates of 100,000 barrels a day or in gas inventories of 10 billion cubic feet, which is a rounding error. All the evidence suggests the market is tightening and reserve additions are disappointing, and we are back in the King Hubbert and peak-oil discussion.     Q: Which suddenly has become an out-of-favor discussion.   A: You know, Cambridge Energy Research Associates came out a couple of months ago with a stinging attack on peak oil. It's the "Peakists" versus the "Cornucopians," which is what Kenneth Deffeyes at Princeton calls the CERA people. Quite frankly, I don't want to be branded either one. The debate is very healthy and no one knows the answers, but there is a lot of evidence that the world's thirst for energy will be reaching a point where we certainly don't want to go the ethanol route.   A bushel of yellow corn is now $4 because of all of the new plans for ethanol production. It has driven up the price of tortillas in Mexico, and people are protesting. It is killing the agriculture and livestock business. A bushel of corn could easily be $5 based on all the new ethanol plants under construction. At a conversion rate of 2.8 gallons of ethanol per bushel, I can tell you without doing much further work that it doesn't work at $5 a bushel for corn and $50 oil.     Q: So how are you investing?   A: We are back to the undervalued parts of the market right now. Natural gas in North America has fallen in price by 50% over the last 12 months. Again, it was up on a spike after the hurricanes, but at this point natural gas recently was trading for as little as $5 a million BTUs at the wellhead. It's at a point that the economics of drilling wells in the U.S. and Canada has caused many companies to lay down rigs and reduce capital budgets.   EnCana [ECA] is probably the most visible company to cut its capital budget for 2007. We think natural gas is still one of the great places to be in terms of an investment theme.     Q: Where would natural gas be more fairly priced?   A: It should be worth its BTU equivalents in crude oil. If crude oil is 55 or so, that would translate into $8 or $9 a million BTUs in natural gas. People have been worried about the inventory overhang that's been a function of the very warm weather we had earlier in the year. But utilities are now burning gas and not oil. The supply of natural gas is still a tremendous issue and we're running up the down escalator in terms of drilling more and more wells to produce the same amount of gas as we did last year.     Q: What about liquefied natural gas?   A: A few years ago, it was thought the liquefied-natural-gas business was going to explode and there'd be all this cheap gas coming into the U.S.   It's turned out the LNG business is not growing at all. Most of the plants that were on the drawing board have been scuttled, and LNG imports to the U.S. were down 8% last year because Spain and other European countries were willing to pay a higher price than was available in the U.S.   It looks very much like the LNG market will be driven by other areas such as Asia and Europe, and we are going to have to get in line and pay a world price. I was worried about the LNG market before, and I'm more worried about it now.     Q: What's happening with the operational plants?   A: There are five LNG regasification facilities that are operational now, and they are and have been chronically underutilized.     Q: What are some of your picks in the natural-gas area?   A: The most undervalued on the basis of a reasonable price tag are the North American exploration and production companies. There are probably 50 companies, but among the ones that are most undervalued are Anadarko Petroleum [APC] and Chesapeake Energy [CHK] and Apache [APA].   We like some of the Canadian companies, EnCana and Canadian Natural Resources, which have tremendous resources in countries that are safe and where you can make a profit. In the case of Canadian Natural [CNQ], for instance, they have an enormous oil-sands investment whose substantial production and profit value is just becoming visible.   Royal Dutch Shell [RDS], because of their impending purchase of Shell Canada, will be able to add in Shell Canada's oil-sands reserves, which have been significantly upgraded. I'm still crazy about the oil sands. I keep telling anybody who doesn't know about the oil sands to buy some and put it in your kids' or your grandkids' account and just forget about it, because it is clearly a unique asset that is economic at much lower oil prices. If prices go to $100 a barrel, it will be phenomenally profitable, because it goes on forever.   We are absolutely convinced the big players there, Suncor Energy [SU], Canadian Natural and Nexen [NXY], are likely to be acquired by the big companies. It is not surprising that Suncor is now starting to show up as rumored target for BP [BP].     Q: That would be huge.   A: That would be a huge deal, but it wouldn't surprise us in any way because BP's portfolio is weak on Canada and weak on oil sands. That's exactly what is going on in the strategic discussions of the large companies: They are trying to figure out where they are going to reinvest their cash flows. Norsk Hydro is being acquired by Statoil [STO] and that makes a lot of sense. Norsk then announced a $700 million write-down of reserves related to its acquisition of Spinnaker Exploration a few years ago.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 00:04 ET (05:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Reporter For Russian Newsweek: Was Assaulted By Extremists
Story: MOSCOW (AP)--A reporter for the Russian language edition of Newsweek said Saturday that he was attacked by nationalist extremists in a Moscow subway station.   Aidar Buribayev said four men with close-cropped hair and black clothing approached him in a subway station just after midnight. One of the men asked if he knew that "Russia was for Russians," he said.   "I replied 'Russia isn't only for Russians,' and he hit me and then the fight started," he said in comments televised on NTV.   He was treated for light injuries, then released. Buribayev is not an ethnic Russian, but his background was not immediately clear.   A Moscow police spokesman confirmed the assault had been reported to police, but had no further information.   Russia has seen a marked rise in xenophobia and racism in recent years, with a series of attacks on nonwhite or dark-skinned residents, foreigners and Jews. Last year, 53 people were killed and another 460 injured in apparent hate crimes, according to the Sova human rights center.   Rights groups say authorities do little to combat the crimes.   Newsweek is owned by Washington Post Co. (WPO).     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 13:19 ET (18:19 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/12) A Bet On Fiber's Future
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jack Willoughby   If you think fiberoptics is so last-century, guess again. Moribund since 2000, investment in Internet infrastructure is accelerating once more, fueled by demand for multimedia services such as online video, publishing and gaming. The resurgent interest is especially evident in the new-issues market, where investor expectations are rising ahead of this week's planned offering of stock in Opnext (the ticker will be OPXT), a maker of fiberoptic modules founded by Hitachi in 2000.   In a deal underwritten by Goldman Sachs, Eatontown, N.J.-based Opnext will offer 16.9 million shares at about $14 apiece. Some 40% will be sold by Hitachi (HIT), which spun off the company in 2001, and venture capitalists including Clarity Partners in Beverly Hills.   The Opnext IPO follows by roughly four months the debut of Optium (OPTM), a near-identical fiberoptic-components start-up that was one of last year's better new issues. Chalfont, Pa.-based Optium came public Oct. 26 for $17.50 and finished the year at $24.95, up 43%. The stock now trades for $23.   Opnext's key draw is its pedigree: that of Hitachi, which will own about 47% of the company after the IPO, and CEO Harry L. Bosco, who spent more than 35 years working with optical-laser networks, mainly at Bell Labs, before joining Hitachi to leverage its fiberoptic expertise into the formation of the new company. The result is a rare pure-play on Japanese leadership in laser technology.   Unlike competitors who buy and repackage fiberoptic components, Opnext manufactures its own. Hitachi has transferred to it more than 670 patents.   Close relationships with data and telecom-network-systems vendors such as Cisco Systems (CSCO) and Alcatel Lucent (ALU) will allow Opnext to ride the next wave of "disruptive" innovation, according to Bosco. These companies are producing optical systems designed increasingly to handle speeds of 10Gbps (gigabytes per second) and, more recently, 40Gbps, Opnext's specialty.   Oregon-based LightCounting, a market-research firm, predicts that demand for 10Gbps data modules will increase to $569 million by 2009, up from $189 million in 2006, a compound annual growth rate of 44%. Over the same span, demand for 10Gbps telecom modules should reach $666 million, up from $357 million, other industry experts say.   Opnext's growth trajectory likewise is impressive. The company reported sales of $157 million in the nine months ended December, versus $105 million in the year-ago period. Net income in the nine months climbed to $925,000, compared with a loss of $27.6 million in 2005. At its road show promoting the IPO, Opnext said it achieved gross margins exceeding 30% in its latest two quarters.   Opnext appears priced to move at $14. According to Paul Bard, a senior analyst at Renaissance Capital in Greenwich, Conn., it will be priced at 2.5 times enterprise value (market value plus net debt) to 2007 estimated revenue of $280 million. This compares favorably with Optium, which trades for 3.5 times enterprise value to '07 revenue. On a price/earnings basis, too, Opnext stands up well. It is expected to trade for 18 times analyst Bard's 2008 earnings estimate of 80 cents a share, versus Optium's P/E of 24.   Paradoxically, its connection with Hitachi may be Opnext's biggest risk. How big, and independent, will Hitachi let the company become? Hitachi has the right to license patent processes to competitors. And, six months after the IPO, both it and Clarity have the right to sell a combined 45 million Opnext shares.   Arguably a less risky, but potentially less rewarding bet on Opnext would be a bet on Hitachi, which trades for 67.17. Not only is the Japanese company midway through an attempted turnaround, but it will pocket close to $100 million from the Opnext IPO.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 00:10 ET (05:10 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Rinnai Corp Conducts Inspections Of Water Heaters Amid Deaths
Story: TOKYO (AP)--Rinnai Corp. (5947.TO), Japan's largest manufacturer of gas appliances, said Saturday that it has begun providing free inspections of its water heaters nationwide following a series of carbon monoxide poisoning linked to three deaths and 12 other injuries, officials said.   The three deaths occurred since October 2003 including the most recent case this week in Kanagawa, just south of Tokyo, and the 12 others have been injured between January 2000 and December 2004, the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry said in a press release issued late Friday.   Rinnai has set up a toll-free number for customers to receive free inspections of three models of water heaters, company official Katsushi Ozawa said Saturday. The models are sold only in Japan.   The company was investigating the cause of the poisonings following an order by the ministry, Rinnai said in a statement.   There are about 1.15 million water heaters of the three models which caused  the poisonings, including one sold by Tokyo Gas Co., and they were produced between 1991 and 1997, according to the ministry release.   Kyodo News agency reported Saturday that two other people died in 11 cases of CO poisoning since 2000 caused by water heaters built by other companies, citing the trade ministry.   The ministry didn't disclose the names of the companies, Kyodo said.   Ministry officials weren't available Saturday.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 02:17 ET (07:17 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/12) Fund Of Information: Can Putnam Prove It s A Buy?
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Lawrence C. Strauss   That Canadian financial firm Great-West Lifeco has agreed to buy beleaguered Putnam Investment Management for $3.9 billion is well-documented. But what isn't as obvious about the deal, expected to close later this year, is whether Great-West Lifeco (ticker: GWO.Canada) paid the right price for the Boston fund firm. Great-West's parent company is Powers Financial, based in Montreal.   Is it a savvy value investment? It's too early to tell how shrewd Great-West's bid is,but the acquisition's success will hinge on turning around the performance of some of Putnam's biggest equity funds.   "What Powers is getting is a major franchise in the biggest market in the world for mutual funds," says Burton Greenwald, a mutual-fund consultant based in Philadelphia. Greenwald describes Putnam as a "pretty strong organization with one gap in equity fund performance."   Some of Putnam's biggest and most high-profile funds have lagged behind their peers and suffered big net outflows. That includes Putnam Growth & Income (ticker: PGRWX), whose three- and five-year annual returns rank in the bottom half of their Lipper and Morningstar peer groups. Additionally, the fund has been hit hard by redemptions. Its assets total about $15.2 billion, down from $32.3 billion at the end of 2000, according to Financial Research Corp.   While the fund shop's net mutual-fund outflows persist, they have lessened in recent years, to about $15 billion in 2006 -- down from nearly $29 billion in 2003.   Putnam also got caught up in the market-timing scandals of 2003 and 2004, costing it dearly in credibility and reputation. But its outflows had begun well before the market-timing snafu, owing to poor relative performance.   On the plus side, President and Chief Executive Charles "Ed" Haldeman, who along with his team will stay on, is highly regarded for trying to steady the Putnam ship, having made some key personnel changes, trimmed costs and brought accountability to the firm.   And there are hints that performance is turning around. For example, Putnam New Value (PANVX), helmed by longtime manager David King, ranks in the top half of its peer groups based on three- and five-year numbers.   "It's definitely a turnaround story," observes Reginald Laing, a fund analyst at Morningstar. "The main thing that's hurt them is retaining talented investment people."   John Casey, chairman of Casey, Quirk & Associates, an asset-management consultancy, says, "It's going to take two to four years [for Putnam] to get its momentum totally back."   Casey estimates that Putnam's annual pretax earnings are "approaching" $400 million, well down from more than $1 billion at the peak before the stock meltdown earlier this decade. Put a multiple of 10 on that, and it's around the $3.9 billion Great-West agreed to pay. That's "within normal industry ratios," Casey says.   If Putnam could increase its assets to $250 billion, versus $200 billion currently, "that essentially falls to the bottom line," Casey says, adding that Putnam "still has an awesome distribution force in place."   Whatever the multiple or metric, the bottom line is that Putnam needs to improve its fund performance, especially in its flagship equity funds, for this deal to make sense.   ---   E-mail: lawrence.strauss@barrons.com   ---               Scoreboard            Myriad Fund Groups Top S&P     -- U.S. diversified equity funds rose an average 0.58% in the week ended Thursday, reports Lipper, Reuters' fund-tracker. In contrast,  the broad market was up 0.22%. Utilities gained 2.06%, and real estate rose 3.03%. Japanese funds lost 2.36%. Headline: =WSJ: Lehman Bros Investment Banker Woody Young Leaves Firm
Story: By Dennis K. Berman   Of THE WALL STREET JOURNAL     One of Lehman Bros. Holdings Inc.'s top investment bankers, Woody Young, has left the firm, according to people familiar with the matter.   As the focal point of Lehman's telecommunications practice, Mr. Young was in the thick of nearly every big telecom merger over the last decade.   (This story and related background material will be available on The Wall Street Journal Web site, WSJ.com.)   It was a fervent period of consolidation, and the deals helped Lehman push its merger advice business into the upper ranks of Wall Street, amid the likes of Morgan Stanley and Merrill Lynch.   The reasons for his departure remained unclear on Saturday, as is Mr. Young's next destination. On Friday, Mr. Young gathered colleagues and disclosed his departure, surprising many of them.   Notable banker moves have been relatively rare over the past few years, largely because a surging investment banking business have delivered sometimes-whopping pay packages to both senior and junior bankers.   Lehman Bros. didn't immediately respond to a request for comment Saturday. Mr. Young declined to comment Friday evening.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 13:14 ET (18:14 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Avalon Oil & Gas Continues to Develop Enhancement Plan for Upshur County, Texas Property
Story: MINNEAPOLIS--(BUSINESS WIRE)--February 10, 2007--   Avalon Oil & Gas, Inc., (OTCBB:AOGS) has made significant progress on the identification of workover opportunities in the New Diana property located in Upshur County, Texas. Avalon and its partners have continued the evaluation of the remaining wells in the field, and have developed preliminary plans to workover at least two wells on the property. The workover plan, procedure, and AFE for the most impactful opportunity are anticipated to be finalized within the next three weeks, with operations on that project to commence soon thereafter. This workover, which will include the replacement of a submersible downhole pump and installation of an incremental saltwater disposal pump, is anticipated to be a cost effective enhancement of production from the Woodbine formation.       About Avalon Oil & Gas, Inc.     Avalon Oil & Gas, Inc. is an oil and gas company engaged in the acquisition of oil and gas producing properties with multiple enhancement opportunities.       Forward-Looking Statements     This press release contains statements, which may constitute "forward-looking statements" within the meaning of the Securities Act of 1933 and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended by the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995.
