Headline: Barron's(2/12) Everybody's Store
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Andrew Bary   "Membership has its privileges." That slogan belongs to American Express, but it might better apply to Costco Wholesale, the leading warehouse-club operator in the U.S., whose determination to deliver value and innovative products to its 23 million members has made it one of the country's top retailers.     -- Costco has succeeded by flouting industry norms. It charges customers a base yearly fee -- now $50 -- to shop in its sprawling stores, which offer quality goods at low mark-ups. Consequently, its margins are among the slimmest in retailing.   The privileges also extend to employees, who are paid well and enjoy generous health-care benefits.     -- This formula has generated fierce loyalty among both shoppers and staff, while rewarding long-term investors. Costco shares (ticker: COST), which traded Friday at 56, are up from a split-adjusted price of $1.67 when the company went public in 1985. True, they no longer are dirt-cheap, but in view of the company's superior management and opportunities for growth, neither are they rich.     -- Small businesses are big customers at Costco, but the company also has managed to make discount shopping fashionable for affluent Americans by offering fine wines, books and big-screen televisions at low prices, and staples like paper towels and razor blades in bulk.   By offering one-time specials like discounted Prada bags or Callaway golf clubs at individual outlets, Costco has created what it calls a "treasure-hunt" atmosphere in its stores. BMWs and Mercedes often crowd Costco parking lots on weekends.   Costco is one of a handful of retailers that has flourished despite Wal-Mart Stores' (WMT) onslaught; Wal-Mart's more downscale Sam's Club chain runs second to Costco. With its strong labor relations, low employee turnover and liberal benefits, Costco has been called an "anti-Wal-Mart." Its approach has paid dividends, because Costco, based in Issaquah, Wash., hasn't encountered the same community resistance as Wal-Mart when it has sought to open new stores.   "Retailing isn't rocket science. Costco has figured out the big, simple things and executed with total fanaticism," says Charles Munger, a Costco director for the past 10 years. The outspoken Munger, 82, is better known as Warren Buffett's long-time partner at Berkshire Hathaway (BRKA), where he serves as vice chairman.   Crucial to the chain's success is CEO Jim Sinegal, who co-founded Costco in 1983 with Jeff Brotman, the company's chairman. "Jim would be on any intelligent list of the top 10 retailers of the past century," Munger says.   Sinegal, 70, also is one of the biggest bargains among big-company CEOs: In an era of seven- and eight-figure pay packages for CEOs, Sinegal earned a salary of $350,000 in Costco's latest fiscal year, which ended in August. He garnered other compensation of about $100,000.   What's more, Sinegal got no bonus last year, after the company determined that it failed to measure properly the appropriate date for certain option grants from 1996 to 2002, although no evidence of fraud or falsification of records was found. "Jim wouldn't let the board give him a bonus. His view was that the option glitch happened on his watch," Munger says. "How many people behave like that? No wonder everyone loves him."   Unlike Buffett, who draws a salary of just $100,000 as CEO of Berkshire, Sinegal isn't a billionaire. He owns Costco stock worth about $135 million and has options on 1.2 million shares.   Sinegal's compensation and demeanor offer a welcome contrast to former Home Depot chief executive officer Robert Nardelli, who alienated employees with his autocratic style and whose gargantuan exit package of $210 million didn't sit well with shareholders. Costco and Home Depot were two of retailing's biggest success stories in the 1990s, but Home Depot has since lost its way while Costco's growth has continued unabated.   None of this has been lost on the investment community. At 56, Costco trades for 22 times fiscal 2007 projected earnings of $2.58 a share. It has one of the highest price/earnings ratios among major retailers. Target (TGT) shares, at 62, trade for 17 times estimated 2007 earnings, while Wal-Mart, at 48, commands 15 times projected 2007 profits.   While some retailing analysts deem Costco shares expensive, the company seems to qualify under one of Buffett's investment dictums. Buffett has said he'd rather buy a good business at fair price than a fair business at a good price. Berkshire owned 5 million Costco shares at the end of September.   This is a genuine growth story. Earnings per share have grown at a 12% annualized rate in the past five years. Neil Currie, a retailing analyst at UBS Securities, believes the company is capable of generating 13% growth in earnings per share in the next few years, and an even higher rate if it gets more aggressive in repurchasing shares. The bullish Currie carries a 12-month price target of $66. With large annual buybacks, Costco could earn more than $4 a share in fiscal 2010, Currie estimates. That could support a stock price of $80.   The company plans to open 36 to 40 new stores in the current fiscal year, and about 35 annually in the following years. The store base totaled 474 on Dec. 31, including 371 in the U.S. Costco says that domestic and international markets ultimately can support more than 1,000 stores. Outside the U.S. and Canada, Mexico, the U.K. and Japan are seen as its most promising markets.   Costco's merchandise sales in its most recent fiscal year rose 14% to $59 billion, while membership fees generated another $1.2 billion of revenue. This year, sales are expected to rise more than 10%, reflecting lower prices for gasoline. Sales at stores open at least year, a key gauge of retailing success, were up a healthy 8% in fiscal 2006. January results, announced last week, fell short of expectations, chiefly due to a change in the calendar.   Could it be a candidate for a leveraged buyout? Costco does possess some of the key characteristics private-equity players seek. It has a strong balance sheet, predictable cash flow and a durable franchise. Its market value is a hefty $26 billion, but LBOs of that size are doable these days. Witness Blackstone Group's winning $39 billion bid for Equity Office Properties Trust (EOP), announced last week.   EOP has $17 billion of debt. Among Costco's attributes is $2 billion of net cash, as well as ownership of 78% of its stores. The stores could be monetized through sale/leasebacks that might generate several billion dollars in proceeds.   Costco bought back $1.5 billion of stock in its latest fiscal year and $400 million in the quarter ended Nov. 30. But it has resisted a large debt-financed buyback like the one under way at Home Depot, and to date it hasn't sought to raise funds through the sale of its real estate. The company takes pride in its impressive financial condition. "Have we gotten to the point in America that balance-sheet strength is a negative?" Munger asks.   Currie argues that Costco could keep LBO operators at bay by launching a more aggressive buyback program and taking on a moderate level of debt. "The best way for Costco to protect its independence is to have a high multiple on its stock," the analyst says, adding that an augmented buyback would help achieve that goal. He believes Costco comfortably can repurchase $2 billion or more of stock annually. The dividend yield on the stock is a low 0.9%.   Its cooperative-like operation makes the retailer's business model unusual. In its latest fiscal year, Costco generated pretax income of $1.75 billion, nearly 70% of which came from membership fees. Another $125 million was kicked in by the interest income on the company's cash. Costco earned just $400 million from its stores, for a retailing operating margin of less than 1%. The low margin is intentional, and reflects the company's commitment to low prices.   As a matter of corporate policy, Costco refuses to mark up any product by more than 15% above its cost. When the company signed a new contract in 2005 with a supplier for Brooks Brothers-style men's cotton, button-down shirts, and got a significant price reduction for a massive two-year order, it immediately cut the price of the shirts to $12.99 from $17.99, notes Richard Galanti, Costco's chief financial officer. Other retailers might have phased in the reduction and captured added profits, but that's not the Costco way. The shirts now cost $14.99 because they are made with better-quality cotton.   One attraction in the eyes of a potential buyer would be the opportunity to lift margins. Costco leads Sam's Club in most financial measurements, including total sales, sales per store, sales per square foot of retail space and sales per employee. But Sam's Clubs' operating profit margin of 3.5% tops Costco's 2.8%.   If Costco were to raise its margins to Sam's level, it would translate into an additional 65 cents a share of net income -- a large amount relative to the current-year consensus estimate of $2.60 a share. Sinegal has talked in the past about lifting Costco's margins to 4%, but little progress has been made.   This has led to some criticism on Wall Street. An analyst report in December, after Costco reported its fiscal first-quarter profits, was entitled "Still no Margin." Galanti says management has no interest in going private. "The public model has worked for us. We have no plans to change," he says.   Many Costco shareholders are also happy with the current situation. "Costco refuses to be undersold, and thinks so long term that the company will not even remotely degrade the value it gives customers, even if it would fuel a healthy increase in margins and earnings and very few customers would notice," says Ken Charles Feinberg, co-manager of the Davis New York Venture Fund (NYVTX) and Selected American Shares (SLADX), both run by Davis Selected Advisors. "That's how a great management builds a great business franchise that's built to last."   The Davis funds are Costco's largest shareholder, with a 12% stake.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 00:02 ET (05:02 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: OPEC Oil Output Down In Jan, But Above Target - Platts Survey
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--The ten members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries bound by the output cut agreement produced an average 26.95 million barrels a day in January, down 50,000 b/d from December's 27 million b/d, according to a Platts survey released late Friday.   The data reveal the group is still 650,000 b/d over its 26.3 million b/d target set in November 2006, and far from reaching the second 25.8 million b/d target imposed Feb. 1.   The group of ten excludes Iraq which doesn't participate in the OPEC output agreement, and new member Angola which is yet to receive and accept an output allocation.   The figures show a 20,000 b/d increase in Nigerian production rising to 2.25 million b/d in January from 2.23 million b/d in December partly offsetting a total 70,000 b/d output decrease achieved by Algeria, Libya, Saudi Arabia and Venezuela.   State-run Nigerian National Petroleum Corp. declared force majeure Friday, as part of an attempt to cut February exports by 250,000 b/d leaving traders waiting for full details of how the cuts will be implemented.   Iraq's January production was sharply down partly because of the 3-day closure of the main Gulf terminal at al-Basrah but also as a result of prolonged bad weather.   The Platts survey backs recent evidence suggesting OPEC is adhering to cuts, a Lloyds Marine Intelligence Unit report Thursday indicated OPEC cut 200,000 barrels-a-day of crude oil exports in January.   Tanker tracker Oil Movements said Thursday OPEC will cut exports by only 120,000 bbl/day in February, well shy of the promised 500,000 bbl/day.     -By Angela Henshall, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)207 842 9285; angela.henshall@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 11:58 ET (16:58 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/12) The Big Question For Big Oil: -2-
Story: We see very few reports where companies have met their production targets, kept their costs down and have projects coming up on time. Instead, everything is delayed, costs more and produces less, which is why we're more in the camp that believes the market is extremely tight and the real challenge is putting the reinvestment dollars to work.     Q: Last year you recommended writing covered calls on energy stocks. Do you still recommend it?   A: It is a brilliant strategy right now. The option premiums are very attractive and the yields are similar. ConocoPhillips [COP] is just as cheap as it was a year ago.   We don't think ExxonMobil [XOM] is the great value it was a year ago. It has had a huge run and a lot of things have gone right, and I don't see it getting a lot better. Royal Dutch Shell now looks like one of the big ones offering a lot better value.     Q: Any other themes emerging?   A: There is a re-emergence of the master limited partnership for upstream companies. Linn Energy [LINE] and EV Energy Partners [EVEP] are two. There has been a tremendous amount of market interest in the midstream companies, companies with pipelines and transportation like Kinder Morgan Energy Partners [KMP], Enterprise Products Partners [EPD] and Plains All American Pipeline [PAA] -- I'm on the board of Plains All American.   The whole sector is very attractive because it distributes a very healthy portion of cash flow and yet continues to reinvest at good rates and grow. They distribute 50% of their cash flow, and they use the other 50% to drill enough wells to keep production and reserves even. They get a great tax advantage because of the cost depletion on your investment.     Q: Will we see what happened in Canada with the income trusts happen here?   A: In Canada, the train stopped when government realized that everything was going to become an income trust. In the case of the U.S., it will take several years of conversion to MLPs before it will become evident to the Government Accountability Office.   The premise of many of these companies is that most of the production in the U.S. is old, tired, depleted fields that decline very slowly and companies should in effect distribute the income to the shareholders and not try and replenish reserves by drilling wildcat wells or in 20,000 feet of water.     Thanks, Art.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 00:04 ET (05:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/12) Asian Trader: Korean Tiger Is Turning Toothless
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Leslie P. Norton   Few equity markets in Asia are as widely disliked as Korea. One of last year's laggards, it has also slumped this year. Blame part of that on the influx of funds into China and India, including those from domestic Koreans. Korea raised rates last year to curb its housing bubble and rising inflation. Worse yet was the rising won, which cut into corporate earnings. Thus, it magnified returns for foreigners -- in toto, the benchmark Korea Composite returned 13% in dollars last year -- but did little to attract domestic investors, who saw the index add just 4%.   Then Pyongyang conducted an underground nuclear test. "The exact date the underperformance began was Oct. 8, the day of the North Korean nuclear test," says Parker Shannon of Samsung Securities America, who sells Korean shares to institutional investors. Next, companies began reporting surprisingly weak earnings.   Thus, though Korea looked cheap at the start of this year, valuations could look less so as fourth-quarter earnings disappoint. So far, some 92 stocks out of the 165 covered by Samsung Securities missed expectations.   Korean equities surely have their fans, including Michael Hartnett, Merrill Lynch's emerging-markets strategist. Hartnett thinks Korea will beat forecasts because it's cheap, foreigners have dumped their shares, and domestic demand could be reviving. Last week, the Bank of Korea left rates unchanged. Korea also made progress on a free-trade agreement with the U.S. and on six-party talks on North Korea's nuclear program, both of which rating agencies would regard favorably.   Yet Hartnett is in the minority. Korea today trades at 10 times earnings, with 15% growth in consensus earnings expectations, versus 12 times and 14.5% for emerging markets as a whole, by the reckoning of George Hoguet, head of emerging markets at State Street Global Investors. (Asia ex-Japan trades at just under 15 times.) "Korea this year is not going to be among the best performing markets," says Hoguet. "The economy is slowing, they have problems in the credit sector, there's the overhang of North Korea, and there are better valuations at places like Brazil, which is at eight times earnings and where EPS growth is almost 20% for the next 12 months."   Last week, Hagju Kim, the Seoul-based strategist for Samsung Securities, reduced his earnings-growth forecast for '07 to 6%. Kim cited more pessimism from Samsung's analysts who cover IT. For one thing, Japanese rivals are expanding capacity as the yen sinks. Today, the yen fetches 7.68 won, versus 9.85 five years ago. Samsung Electronics (ticker: 005930.SE), the market bellwether, faces increased competition from Taiwan. Demand growth for displays has peaked, while handset manufacturers are suffering from competition at the high end and from a strong won at the low end. Automakers, meanwhile, are hit by a high won and laggard technology to address stricter emissions rules.   In the recent past, domestic investors, newly enamored of their stock market, could be counted on to buy stock mutual funds. Yet lately, Seoul has encouraged equity investment overseas to curb even greater rises in the won. Thus, Korean investors are happily buying foreign shares.   Korean stocks have traditionally suffered from a "Korea discount" that reflects the potential dangers of the market's proximity to Pyongyang and also perceived failings in corporate governance. Last week, Chung Mong-Koo, the chairman of Hyundai Motor (005380.SE), which accounts for 2.18% of the Kospi, received a three-year prison sentence for embezzlement. A blizzard of executives across corporate Korea have been arrested or convicted for a spate of offenses including bribery, though few have served jail time.   At the same time, disclosure has actually improved, brightening the picture for foreign investors. Yet government policies are also chilling investment, say critics like Mark Headley, who runs Matthews Korea Fund. President Roh Moo-Hyun has stymied the property market by discouraging building, perversely driving prices higher, says Headley. Roh has also boosted corporate regulation. Says Headley: "It's no longer a corporate-governance discount; it's a government discount."   What could drive Korean equities higher? Bargain hunting and a subsequent narrowing of the discount to more normal levels. That could drive the Kospi index to 1467 this year from last week's 1427, says Kim of Samsung Securities. Still, he adds, it's tough to expect higher prices without greater earnings growth.   The bright spot could be the forthcoming presidential election, scheduled for Dec. 19. The former mayor of Seoul, Lee Myung-bak, has a commanding lead, followed by Park Geun-hye, the daughter of former military dictator Park Chung Hee. Both are viewed as much more business friendly than Roh, who by law can't seek another term. Still, Headley of Matthews sighs, "that's a second-half story. There's no real catalyst until then."   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 00:09 ET (05:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/12) 13D Filings: Investors Report To The SEC
Story: (From BARRON'S)   13Ds are supposed to be filed within 10 days of an entity's attaining 5% or more of any class of a company's securities. Subsequent changes must be reported on amended filings. This material is from filings released by the SEC from Feb. 1 through 7.   Source: Corporate Filings Alert     Activists     Yardville National Bancorp (YANB)   Shareholder Lawrence Seidman is asking Yardville to disclose information about jobs given to relatives of executives and directors. Seidman says that CEO Patrick Ryan employed his son as a senior vice president and as a manager of the company's banking unit, and that Yardville recently  hired an investment banker that employed another Ryan son. Seidman also said that Chairman Jay G. Destribats' son worked for a law firm that received significant legal fees from Yardville, and that at least three other relatives of Yardville directors and senior management work for the company. Seidman holds 993,435 shares (8.99% of the total outstanding).     Flow International (FLOW)   Third Point is urging a sale of the company. Third Point CEO Daniel S. Loeb said in a letter that he's disappointed by the retirement of Flow International's CEO, Stephen R. Light. Loeb said he had invested in the company based on his confidence in Light's leadership. Third Point owns 5.06 million shares (13.6%).     C&D Technologies (CHP)   Sun Capital Securities' Michael H. Kalb was elected to serve on C&D's board and nominating committee. Sun Capital and C&D have agreed to nominate Kalb for election, and Sun Capital will vote for C&D's director nominees at the 2007 annual meeting. Sun Capital has about 3.12 million shares (12.2%).     Original Filings     Repligen (RGEN)   Investor Ronald L. Chez owns 1,567,221 shares (5.2%), after buying 187,391 from Dec. 1, 2006, to Jan. 30, at prices ranging from $2.67 to $3.25.     Increases in Holdings     Ceridian (CEN)   Activist investor William Ackman's Pershing Square Capital Management raised its holdings to 18.72 million shares (13.5%) from the 15.72 million (11.3%) it reported on Jan. 23.     MDS (MDZ)   ValueAct Partners owns 19,329,300 shares (13.4%), after buying 1,618,700 from Jan. 5 to Feb. 2 at $17.01 to $17.75 each.     Decreases in Holdings     Stride Rite (SRR)   Investors including Barington Companies Equity Partners cut their holdings to 1,739,599 shares (4.82%) by selling 415,000 from Jan. 22 to Feb. 2 at $16.87 to $17.67 a share.     Advo (AD)   UBS (UBS) trimmed its stake to about 1.9 million shares (less than 5%) by selling 362,600 from Jan. 26 to Feb. 2, at prices ranging from $32.71 to $32.80.     Ingles Markets (IMKTA)   Funds run by Mario Gabelli's Gamco Investors (GBL) own 884,400 shares (7.19%), after selling 32,000 from Jan. 24 to Feb. 1 at $32.99 to $39.04 a share.     Flowers Foods (FLO)   Funds run by Gamco Investors own 3,129,083 shares (5.15%), after selling 144,000 at $26.22 to $28.74 a share.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 00:04 ET (05:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/12) Singapore: The Safest Route To Asia's Riches
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Kopin Tan   As a rule, small tropical islands have an obligation to the rest of the world to preserve themselves as sun-filled, rum-soaked, licentious getaways. But Singapore doesn't do laid-back very well. Nearly 4,200 flights take off and land each week at its bustling airport, and its port is the world's busiest. At 4.41 million, the number of mobile-phone users exceeds its adult population, and sometimes they all seem to be talking at once. Even Singapore's national pastimes -- eating and shopping -- are pursued with a ferocity that might make a New Yorker blush.   These days, there is nothing laid back about its stock market's performance, either. The iShares MSCI Singapore Fund, an exchange-traded fund listed at the New York Stock Exchange (ticker: EWS), rallied 42% in 2006 and is up 8.7% this year. The Singapore Fund (SGF), a U.S.-listed closed-end fund, surged 64% last year and has added another 8.7% in 2007. The country's benchmark Straits Times Index is at a record peak.   The Singapore market has even begun to outpace the bourses in Korea, Taiwan and other "Asian tigers" it once closely tracked. This divergence is only partly explained by the strength of Singapore's banking and real-estate sectors, which helped sustain the city-state through the global technology sector's recent weakness.   The extent of its outperformance -- comparable ETFs for Taiwan (EWT) and South Korea (EWY) rose just 16% and 10%, respectively, last year -- suggests something else is at work: Singapore's successful transformation into a teeming financial hub, with a rising profile as the gateway to Asia's booming economies.   Singapore's push to become the Switzerland of Asia has impressed even Felix Zulauf, head of Zurich-basedZulauf Asset Management and a member of Barron's Roundtable: "I think it will become the offshore financial center of Asia." He picked the Singapore ETF as "a classic way to play the rise of Asia, and the mania I see coming" (see "2007 Barron's Roundtable, Part 2," Jan. 22). Although the ETF's recent surge makes it vulnerable to a short-term correction, it has the potential to roughly double by 2010, says Zulauf.   Singapore's transformation is born of necessity. A tiny Southeast Asian country half the size of Los Angeles, it has no natural resources; it even imports water from neighboring Malaysia. Recognizing that it cannot compete with China or India as a source of cheap labor, Singapore has revamped its manufacturing base to focus on higher-value-added industries like financial services, biomedical research, technology and oil refining.   But Singapore does have the gift of geography. With China and Japan to the north, India to the west and Australia to the southeast, the former British colony has always been a key port along the area's shipping routes.   Today, thanks to an established financial and transportation infrastructure, it is also a portal to Asian Pacific markets. Among its attractions for companies seeking regional bases: generous tax breaks; an educated workforce (the literacy rate is 95%, and 56% are at least bilingual); virtually no corruption; scant crime; a rigorous legal system and -- this cannot be overestimated -- fabulous food.   When its annual budget is announced Feb. 15, Singapore is expected to cut its corporate tax rate by at least one percentage point, from 20%, to help keep pace with Hong Kong's 17.5% and Ireland's 12.5%.   The pro-business stance of its essentially one-party government -- steered for 25 of its 42 years by founding Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew -- is key to its competitiveness. Singapore's GDP expanded nearly 8% last year, and is projected to grow 6% this year, even as global growth brakes. A strong Singapore dollar (worth about 67 U.S. cents), inflation below 1%, unemployment of 2.5% and 10-year Treasury yields at 3.18% all point to safe, steady growth.   Money-manager Zulauf isn't the only one singing the country's praises. A 2007 World Bank report names Singapore "the world's easiest place to do business." A KPMG study of 128 cities last year picked Singapore as the most cost-competitive for business, with expenses 22% below those in the U.S. Singapore also topped Standard & Poor's ranking of Asian countries by fiscal prudence, with the government projected to sock away 5% of its 2007 GDP -- ahead of even oil-rich Kazakhstan.   To be sure, Singapore's export-dependent market will falter in a global recession. It did not escape the Asian financial crisis and suffered through the 2001 recession and the ensuing SARS-epidemic scare. And despite diversification, its electronics manufacturing and information-technology sectors could be a drag on the market if technology demand slumps.   Singapore's fortunes also depend heavily on China's hardly assured continuing prosperity. But its unique status -- a developed country surrounded by developing ones, a stable bridge to emerging markets -- offers one of the most balanced and appealing risk-reward profiles among Asian ETFs.   Singapore stocks are now more fully valued, given their recent surge. According to Heckman Global Advisors, a unit of Bear Stearns Asset Management, Singapore is no longer cheap based on conventional metrics like price-earnings ratios. But a price-to-book ratio of 2.3 times still looks cheap compared with the average 2.7 times among developed economies. More important, earnings momentum -- the portion of companies with upward earnings revisions -- ranks Singapore third among 23 developed countries.   The first things you notice in Singapore -- after the lush greenery -- are the crowds. With full employment and its multi-ethnic population growing just 1.8% annually, the government has eased labor restrictions to boost its workforce, and throngs of Indonesian maids, Thai construction workers and Chinese waitresses -- all holding jobs that locals shun -- help make Singapore a land of aspiration.   The standard of living is high. Luxury emporiums from Armani to Zegna all have their outposts, and at the Raffles Hotel, a Singapore Sling will set you back US$14.   The good life, stable outlook and scarce land all bode well for Singapore's banking and real-estate sectors. The EWS is heavily weighted toward financials (36%), followed by real estate (16%), capital goods (14%), telecommunications services (12%), transportation (9%) and media (4%).   UBS, for example, expects local bank profits to increase 14% in 2007 after a 15% rise in 2006. While higher interest rates were a catalyst last year, strong loan growth will drive 2007 profits as construction and consumer lending increase.   Despite last year's rally, bank valuations remain reasonable at 1.75 times book, or accounting, value. UBS analyst Jaj Singh argues that they should be higher because average valuations over the past eight years tracked a deflationary period, and "a more relevant period is the early 1990s." Then, banks traded at 2.6 times book value; UBS' target ratio today is 1.9. In the banking group, DBS, or Development Bank of Singapore (DBS.Singapore), boasts strong deposits, low funding costs and a 67% loan-to-deposit ratio that leaves much room for expansion.   Sure, the night life isn't as, well, colorful, as Bangkok's, and stiff drug laws -- some carrying mandatory death penalties -- mean that any wild partying is fueled, at most, by Grey Goose and Red Bull. But that hasn't deterred 9.7 million visitors who flocked to Singapore last year, sending tourism revenue up 14.5%, to $8.3 billion.   Not satisfied, Singapore plans to build a pair of giant "integrated resorts" -- casinos, hotels, malls and convention halls -- on its marina bay and on Sentosa, a nearby theme-park island rivaling Vegas in artifice. Construction begins with investments of about $5 billion each from Las Vegas Sands (LVS) and Malaysia's Genting International (GIL.Singapore) -- and analysts see thousands of new jobs by the time these open in three years.   Painful as it is to buy property today, Singapore real-estate prices, which have begun to rebound, are still nearly 30% off their 1996 peaks and are moderate compared with cities like Tokyo and Hong Kong.   The brightening outlook extends to both residential and commercial properties. General Electric (GE), for example, bought a midsize office tower last year and plans to "significantly build up the Singapore portfolio over the next three years," says Mark Hutchinson, the Asia-Pacific head of GE Real Estate. Sean Monaghan, a Singapore-based Merrill Lynch analyst, expects rising demand and constricted new supply to drive prime office rents up 45% to S$12.80 a square foot by 2009.   Among Monaghan's picks are CapitaLand (CAPL.Singapore), one of Singapore's largest office landlords and a manager of 13 malls in Singapore, four in Japan and 70 in China; Keppel Land (KPLD.Singapore), one of the largest property companies listed on the Singapore Stock Exchange; and City Developments (CIT.Singapore), a property developer and hotel manager that owns nearly 2.4 million square feet of office stock.   Singapore's economy should thrive for years. Even in a worldwide recession, you have to respect the odds of a country that has defied its limitations and reclaimed 17% of its land from the sea. And should Asia become an engine of global economic growth in the decades ahead, Singapore will be one of the drivers.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 00:03 ET (05:03 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Total SA Facing Trial In France For 1999 Oil Spill
Story: PARIS (AP)--A trial to open Monday will decide whether oil company Total SA (12027.FR) was responsible for France's worst-ever oil spill, a 1999 shipwreck that left much of the country's Atlantic coastline covered with gummy black oil.   The Maltese-registered "Erika" tanker, hauling fuel oil owned by a unit of Total, split in two and sank in rough seas on Dec. 12, 1999. About 20,000 metric tons of oil leaked into the Atlantic and washed up on the coastline, killing thousands of birds and blackening beaches.   Total faces charges of pollution and "complicity in endangering people and property." In a document ordering Total to stand trial, Investigating Judge Dominique de Talance said the company disregarded its own safety standards by chartering a 25-year-old ship.   The magistrate also wrote that the company had been informed by crew a day before the spill that "leaks due to cracks in the deck raised fears of pollution."   Total, which says the charges were unfounded, has noted that the company already paid $241 million to clean France's beaches, pump oil out of the ship and treat the waste.   The trial's head judge, Jean-Baptiste Parlos, is expected to focus the hearings on the events leading up to the spill. Hearings are expected to wrap up in June.   Others to be brought before the court in the case include Italian company Registro Italiano Navale, or RINA, which had inspected the vessel before it sank; Erika's captain Karun Mathur; Antonio Pollara, an official with the Italian company Panship who was in charge of technical assistance; and Erika's owner Giuseppe Savarese.   Judicial experts who worked on the penal inquiry faulted the ship's owner for insufficient upkeep of the boat and "for not taking any measures on Dec. 11 and 12, though he knew the seriousness of the situation." Savarese has contested the charges.   Two Total units, Total Transport Corp. and Total Gas and Power Services Ltd., formerly known as Total Petroleum Services, will also be tried.   The Erika crisis was one of several disasters that led EU transport ministers to tighten controls on maritime safety. France also toughened its own laws.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 09:09 ET (14:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/12) The Vital Signs Look Good
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jacqueline Doherty   Few companies have been hit harder by accusations of stock-option backdating than UnitedHealth Group, the giant health-care insurer. Allegations that the company lined management's pocket by altering the date of options grants resulted last year in the departure of former CEO William McGuire and a member of the board of directors. UnitedHealth (ticker: UNH) hasn't filed a quarterly financial report with the Securities and Exchange Commission since last year's first quarter, because it still hasn't determined the accounting treatment for formerly issued options. The company faces shareholder lawsuits and investigations by the SEC, the Internal Revenue Service and the U.S. attorney for the Southern District of New York. And its shares, which once topped 63, now trade for 51.   Yet, for all its maladies, the patient is alive and kicking -- vigorously, in fact. UnitedHealth's underlying business is strong and growing, and it is hard to imagine its fortress-like balance sheet, with $2.6 billion of net cash, can't absorb any fines or accrued taxes the company is likely to owe.   Indeed, the Minnetonka, Minn.-based insurer still is considered among the best in the business, hailed for its sophisticated use of technology, innovative culture and nationwide network of health-care providers. (Barron's Online extolled the company's virtues last fall. See "UnitedHealth Facing Clearer Skies," Oct. 25.)   "UnitedHealth has great prospects and potential," says CEO Stephen Hemsley, noting that spending on health care is expected to double to $4 trillion by 2015. "You can hardly find an enterprise in the health-care space that is better positioned and has our diversification."   Last year, UnitedHealth generated $7 billion of operating earnings on revenue of $71.7 billion. Although the company cut its revenue estimate for 2007 last week because of disappointing enrollment trends in its Medicare-insurance unit, it continues to target annual revenue growth of 10% and earnings growth of 15% over the longer term. (Revenue this year is expected to grow 9%, to $78 billion.)   Even better, UnitedHealth's insurance and medical-services businesses throw off copious amounts of cash; operating cash flow could top $6 billion this year. Once its regulatory filings are current, the company is expected to launch an aggressive stock-buyback program, repurchasing perhaps as much as $6 billion of stock.   UnitedHealth currently trades for 15 times estimated 2007 earnings of $3.42 a share, and 13 times '08 estimates of $3.93. Historically, the stock has bottomed at about 13 times trailing 12-month earnings, and peaked near 30 times. The company sells for a small but deserved premium to its closest competitors, Aetna (AET) and Cigna (CI), because of its greater exposure to the fast-growing Medicare and Medicaid business.   Some of Wall Street's smartest investors are betting UnitedHealth's stock will follow profits higher. Omega Advisors, for one, holds roughly 1.1 million of the company's 1.4 billion shares, and expects its price/earnings multiple to expand to 17 on $4 a share of earnings in 2008. That implies a price of 68 a share, some 30% above current levels.   "All of UnitedHealth's metrics are significantly ahead of the market," says David Mandelbaum, an Omega partner. He points to the company's 7.5% free-cash-flow yield (cash flow divided by market capitalization), 22% return on equity and strong earnings growth.   UnitedHealth has "a very favorable risk/reward profile," adds Kenny Kan, an analyst at Legg Mason Capital Management, another large shareholder. If more bad news surfaces, the shares could return to the low 40s. More likely, says Kan, the company will continue to cut costs, grow profits and buy back shares. He expects the stock to trade in the 70s in 12 to 24 months.   UnitedHealth sells health insurance to corporations and coverage to individuals receiving Medicare and Medicaid. It also sells technology and outsourced services to health-care providers. In the past five years, annual sales have grown by more than 27%, and profits by 34%.   Those results owe much to acquisitions, however. PacifiCare Health Systems, purchased in 2005 for $8.1 billion, added 3 million members to UnitedHealth's roster, as well as exposure to the California health-care market and expertise in providing health insurance to seniors covered by Medicare. Prior to that, the company purchased Oxford Health Plans and Mid Atlantic Medical Service, providers of health-care benefits and services to large companies. This year will be a test of UnitedHealth's ability to grow organically.   The options scandal was a rude awakening to fans of this one-time market darling. A report by a prominent law firm completed in October for a special committee of UnitedHealth's board concluded that option-grant dates likely were backdated, or reset after the fact to reflect a lower stock price on the date of issue, for most of the executive stock options granted between 1994 and 2006. The practice, illegal under some circumstances and unethical under most, effectively maximizes the profit an option holder potentially could capture upon exercise.   According to the report, most of the option dates were chosen by McGuire, who led the company for 15 years. Option recipients included top executives, among them Hemsley, 54, the long-time president who was named CEO upon McGuire's departure. An attorney for McGuire said in an e-mail: "While neither a lawyer nor accountant, Dr. McGuire believed that the processes by which options were granted were transparent, appropriate, and approved. Indeed, experts who reviewed these processes never raised concerns at the time about the stock-options program."   Hemsley declined to comment on option-related issues because of pending regulatory and legal matters.   The company's senior managers have agreed to reset any improper grant dates for options doled out between 1994 and '02, giving up both realized and paper gains. For Hemsley, it means forfeiting $190 million; for McGuire, $200 million.   Notwithstanding the lack of federal filings, the company has issued regular updates on its operations and the results of its six divisions. The largest, UnitedHealthcare, is expected to generate about $36.6 billion of revenue next year, up 4%. It sells insurance to small and mid-sized companies, individual businesses and public organizations such as municipalities and labor unions. It covers 14.8 million people, and has operating margins of about 8%.   The Uniprise division sells health insurance and services to companies with more than 5,000 employees. UnitedHealth believes the segment can generate about $6 billion of revenue this year, up 7% from '06, and about $1 billion of operating income.   To be sure, the UnitedHealth story still has plenty of skeptics. One of Wall Street's most public is Matthew Borsch, a Goldman Sachs analyst with a Sell recommendation on the stock and a $47 price target. He warns that the company faces merger-integration risk and a cyclical slowdown in its commercial business. UnitedHealth counters that the cycles are regional, not national, with strength in some markets offsetting sharp price competition in others. Also, industry consolidation has resulted in fewer, larger players with better pricing information, which should lead to more rational decision-making.   UnitedHealth's second-largest unit by revenue is Ovations, targeting people over 50. It is expected to contribute $28 billion of sales, up almost 19% from '06. The unit runs a Medicare-supplement business, called Medicare Advantage, as well as a new Medicare Part D prescription-drug program.   The last has been a surprising success. Launched in January 2006, it has the endorsement of the AARP, at least through 2008. UnitedHealth's Part D operation, already boasts 5.74 million customers and $5.7 billion in '06 revenue.   Enrollment trends in Medicare Advantage have been a worry. Last week, the company said membership would fall by up to 100,000 in the current quarter, well below earlier estimates. The program has slim margins, and UnitedHealth hopes to meet earlier earnings targets via cost-cutting.   The disappointment appears to stem from a problem at PacifiCare, late sales and marketing materials and not paying outside sales representatives adequate commissions. "It does not seem that complicated to fix," says Doug Lane of Douglas C. Lane & Associates, a New York-based money manager that owns the shares. "The business is there if they do it right."   Rival Humana (HUM) reported strong sales, proving as much.   UnitedHealth's AmeriChoice unit, which serves state Medicaid and Children's Health Insurance programs, could generate $4.4 billion in revenue this year, owing in part to the addition of Tennessee and Washington. The unit will benefit if more states seek to provide health-care coverage to the uninsured.   If Congress, seeking more savings, puts the squeeze on reimbursements to health-care organizations, UnitedHealth's margins will suffer. Likewise, strapped states could cut funds from their Medicaid budgets. But UnitedHealth's diversification -- the company also sells technology, clinical research and drug-safety services to other health-care companies -- insulates it to a degree.   Although the option scandal dented UnitedHealth's reputation, the company's business remains robust. In coming months, the news is likely to get even better for this well-run insurer, no matter what the headlines might suggest.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 00:05 ET (05:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UK PRESS: Poultry Sales Begin To Fall
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)-- Consumers' fears over bird flu are beginning to bite, with J Sainsbury (SBRY.LN), Britain's third-largest supermarket chain, reporting a 10% fall in poultry sales over the past five days,  the Financial Times reports Saturday citing company sources.   The retailer, which last weekend said it hadn't seen any change in sales despite news that the H5N1 bird flu virus had been detected on a Suffolk farm of Bernard Matthews, said buying patterns were beginning to change, reports the paper.   It writes, Tesco (TSCO.LN) the UK's largest retailer, said it had also seen a "slight dip". The paper adds that Tesco refused to comment on whether that trend had worsened over the course of the week.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.ft.com   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9320     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 08:51 ET (13:51 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/12) Follow-Up: Savvy Moves Position CIT For Gains
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Christoper C. Williams   CIT Group has posted an operating profit in each of its 98 years. It's a good bet the commercial-lending giant hits the century mark with annual-profit skein intact, given better-than-expected fourth-quarter results and a new asset-management strategy. If it does, CIT's stock (ticker: CIT), up 19% in the past 12 months, could get another boost. Analysts expect 2008 profits to grow 9%, to $1.184 billion, from an expected $1 billion this year.   The market is rewarding CIT for its Steady Eddie performance. The stock hit a yearly high of 61.59 Wednesday and is up 22% since Barron's praised CIT's strategy in a follow-up in 2005 ("CIT Has Soared Flying Solo," Nov. 14, 2005). We first recommended CIT at 32 in 2003.   High expenses and exposure to the slumping sub-prime mortgage market pose challenges, but last month management raised its 2007 earnings outlook, underscoring Chairman Jeffrey Peek's contention that "CIT has never been stronger or better positioned for the future."   CIT trades for 10 times analysts' 2008 earnings estimates of $6.06 a share and could climb to 67 as the company expands, says Soleil analyst Craig Maurer.   CIT "has built a focused sales culture for the first time in its history, and it is clear those efforts are paying off," he says, citing greater loan originations.   Maurer and others applaud CIT's move to generate more revenue from fees, which are less volatile than net interest margin. Peek sees fees reaching 50% of revenue in the next six quarters.   Some insiders have been selling shares recently in option-related transactions, but Peek isn't a seller. "If we can achieve our previously announced earnings-growth objectives, get return on common equity to 15% and become more of an asset manager, I'd like to hope we get another point or so on our forward earnings multiple," he says.   We'll be watching.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 00:07 ET (05:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/12) Tech Trader: Biopharma Giant Set To Rule Insulin Market
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Bill Alpert   With diabetes expected to double its prevalence worldwide by 2030 -- to nearly 400 million people -- Novo Nordisk should have growing demand for its insulin products. The Danish firm (ticker: NVO) has been the leader in sales of insulin-related products everywhere in the world except the U.S. If Novo's well-regarded products can take more market share here, as they have abroad, the company's American depositary shares may continue their 2006 climb, which  has taken them to  $90.44.   "The U.S. is the only country where we were not leaders," said Novo's chief executive, Lars Rebien Sorensen, the other day in  New York. "For many years, we were the underdogs." But Novo has been on a roll, winning patients and doctors over to its "insulin-analog" products. These variants of the human-insulin molecule work somewhat better, sell for about twice the price and enjoy patent protection for a number of years to come.   Novo and its rivals, Eli Lilly (LLY) and Sanofi-Aventis (SNY), have gotten about half of insulin-using diabetics to change to analog products. Yet Novo's winning more than its share of those converts, because its product line is the most complete and its prepackaged injection devices the most convenient.   In 2006, Novo sales of its insulin analogs jumped by almost 50%. Overall, Novo sales grew 29% in the U.S. and 15% worldwide to 5.2 billion euros (or $6.75 billion). Earnings per share grew 12% to 2.68 euros -- that's about $3.50 per depositary share, for a price-earnings ratio of 26 times 2006 earnings.   Growth stories are scarce in today's drug industry, but can Novo continue to merit such an earnings multiple?   I don't see why not. The diabetes plague is turning up everywhere. China contributed more than 40% of Novo's international growth last year.   The highly automated Danish company is meeting generic-insulin competitors head-on. Regulations appeared in Europe last year to allow generic competition in bioengineered products like insulin (see "Biotech's New Battlefield," May 22, 2006). Novo and Sanofi-Aventis have outrun the threat of such "biosimilars" by persuading doctors and patients of the superiority of insulin analogs over insulin. When a government-sponsored study in Germany concluded otherwise -- saying that analog products were no better -- diabetes sufferers objected.   In the U.S., government regulators have dragged their feet in accommodating biosimilar generics. In markets where such generic recombinant insulins do appear, says chief executive Sorensen, Novo can compete with its production efficiency and its prefilled devices. "We used to be a generic manufacturer ourselves," says Sorensen. "We can outcompete anyone."   Novo has a couple of other growth opportunities, in addition to its insulin analogs. It is in Phase III trials with an incretin product similar to Byetta, the successful new diabetes treatment produced by Amylin Pharmaceuticals (AMLN) and sold by Lilly. Diabetes experts who recently spoke to clients of Credit Suisse said they were looking forward to Novo's drug -- which patients need only take once a day, compared to Amylin's twice-a-day product. Study results will start appearing in August. If Novo's drug tests well, it could get to market in 2009. Amylin is testing an even longer-acting Byetta, but the product requires a large needle.   A second, more speculative prospect for Novo is the use of its hemophilia drug NovoSeven in bleeding-trauma patients and in heart surgery. As reported in an excellent series of stories in the Baltimore Sun in November, NovoSeven is already being used off-label by military doctors in Iraq to stop soldiers' bleeding -- a desperate and controversial practice that may or may not benefit soldiers in the long run. A controlled trial can best answer the question, and Novo will test the drug in about 1,500 trauma patients in the U.S. and a similar number abroad.   Novo is also testing NovoSeven in patients who've suffered a bleeding stroke. Every seemingly promising stroke drug has failed to prove truly effective when tested rigorously -- as investors saw most recently with the Phase III failure of an experimental drug from Renovis (RNVS). Yet Phase II studies abroad suggested that Novo's drug was effective at stemming stroke patients' bleeds, so hope remains for that treatment. With about 85,000 bleeding strokes a year in the U.S., Europe and Japan, a successful stroke outcome for NovoSeven could add $400 million a year in sales for Novo.   Novo has tried in the past to diversify beyond diabetes and injectable products. But for the moment, it looks like it's in the right place.   Stockbroker Mike Zelvin thinks Motorola's December agreement to buy Tut Systems was a smart deal, and so he's mad as hell.   Zelvin is a broker at little Brill Securities who spent more than two years studying Tut's technology for sending television down phone lines to people's homes. He and his clients had accumulated a decent position in Tut (TUTS) as that company alluded to $200 million in contracts it was pursuing with an unnamed, large equipment provider, which Zelvin inferred was Motorola (MOT), for an unnamed telecom customer, which Zelvin inferred was Verizon Communications (VZ). Zelvin figured that when Verizon and other phone companies finally got into TV in a big way, Tut would enjoy $100 million in annual revenue and 62 cents a share in earnings (not even counting its tax-loss benefits). Zelvin concluded that Tut shares were easily worth $3 to $4.   But Tut agreed on Dec. 20 to be bought by Motorola for $1.15 a share, or $39 million-scarcely above where the shares had been trading.  Zelvin is angry. "It really hurt me," he complains.   In their merger proxy, the companies disclose that Tut had nearly run out of money waiting for the phone industry's TV rollout. Cash on Tut's balance sheet had ebbed to $4.6 million in September. The company's banker declined to count the telecom-TV opportunity in his fairness opinion -- seeing as Tut's back was against the wall.   Zelvin isn't part of a Delaware state court class-action suit that's protesting Tut's failure to obtain a pricier buyout. But he sees Motorola's payment as unseemly. "It's like an orphan was on the street with his cup out and a millionaire gives him a quarter," says Zelvin. "The orphan is happy, but the millionaire should've really given him the $10 bill he was carrying in his pocket."   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 00:08 ET (05:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Chrysler Pondering Buyouts For Canada Auto Workers -Report
Story: NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--The Canadian Auto Workers are negotiating with Chrysler to secure buyouts and early retirement offers for as many workers as possible, a top union official told The Detroit News.   The report quoted CAW Local 444 President Ken Lewenza as saying that, "Chrysler has shown a unique willingness in these discussions to treat (the layoffs) as humanely as possible."   Lewenza is the chairman of the union's master bargaining committee at DaimlerChrysler AG (DCX). He is the first official involved in the negotiations to publicly confirm the U.S. arm of DaimlerChrysler is preparing buyouts for factory workers as part of a restructuring expected to be announced Wednesday, the report said.   Lewenza said CAW officials are using Ford Motor Co.'s (F) recent buyout and early retirement offers as a model in their negotiations. Among the incentives being discussed with the Canadian union are C$70,000 payouts to senior employees who are eligible for retirement, lump-some payouts to younger employees who would agree to walk away and give up all benefits, and incentives such as vouchers good toward the purchase of a Chrysler vehicle.   No final deal has been hammered out and union bargainers and senior Chrysler officials are preparing to negotiate through the weekend in Auburn Hills, Lewenza said. Local 444 represents Canadian Chrysler employees who work at assembly plants in Windsor and Brampton, Ontario.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 02:45 ET (07:45 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : N. James Tees and Sarene A. Bourdages Named Executive Vice Presidents of Max Re Capital Ltd.
Story: HAMILTON, Bermuda--(BUSINESS WIRE)--February 10, 2007--   Max Re Capital Ltd. (NASDAQ: MXRE; BSX: MXRE BH) today announced that N. James Tees, previously the Company's Senior Vice President, Treasurer and Secretary, has been named Executive Vice President and Chief Risk Officer, effective immediately.     Max Re Capital also announced that Sarene A. Bourdages, previously the Company's Senior Vice President and General Counsel, has been promoted to Executive Vice President and General Counsel, also effective immediately.     W. Marston Becker, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Max Re Capital, said: "I'm pleased to congratulate Jim and Sarene, who are already important members of our senior management team, on these well-deserved promotions."     Mr. Tees joined Max Re Capital in April 2000, and most recently served as the Company's Senior Vice President and Treasurer. From 1991 to 2000, he served as Vice President and Controller for Stockton Holdings Limited, a reinsurance business pursuing a diversified, global investment strategy. Mr. Tees, a CPA, began his career in 1980 at the public accounting firm of Coopers & Lybrand, where he was a senior audit manager. He is a member of both the American and Pennsylvania Institute of Certified Public Accountants. In addition to his responsibilities in his new role, Mr. Tees will continue to manage Max Re's relations with investors, banks and rating agencies.     Ms. Bourdages joined Max Re Capital in November 2002. From 1999 to 2002, she was an associate at Akin Gump Strauss Hauer & Feld, LLP in New York. From 1996 to 1999, she worked in international tax consulting at KPMG LLP. She earned her Juris Doctor and Master of Laws (International and Comparative Law) from Duke University School of Law in 1996 and her Bachelor of Arts in French and Political Science from the University of Missouri-Columbia in 1993. Ms. Bourdages is a member of the New York Bar.     Max Re Capital Ltd., through its principal operating subsidiaries, Max Re Ltd., Max Insurance Europe Limited and Max Re Europe Limited, provides insurance and reinsurance products to corporations, public entities, property and casualty insurers and life and health insurers.     This release includes statements about future expectations, plans and prospects of the Company that constitute forward-looking statements for purposes of the safe harbor provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Such forward-looking statements are subject to certain risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those suggested by such statements, including the risk that the SEC's view of the conclusions reached by the Audit and Risk Management Committee of the Company's Board of Directors in connection with the internal review of three finite risk retrocessional contracts written in 2001 and 2003, which caused the Company to restate its audited financial statements for the years ended December 31, 2005, 2004, 2003, 2002 and 2001 and unaudited financial statements for the periods ended March 31, 2006 and June 30, 2006, may differ, perhaps materially, and result in material changes to information contained in the Company's past SEC filings, including financial statements and financial information. For further information regarding cautionary statements and factors affecting future results, please refer to the Company's Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q/A for the period ended September 30, 2006 and other documents filed by the Company with the SEC. The Company undertakes no obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statement whether as a result of new information, future developments or otherwise. Headline: Barron's(2/12) Sizing Up Small Caps: Drug Tests: Spitting Into The Wind
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jim McTague   In the lucrative business of drug and alcohol testing, the venerable plastic collection cup is being challenged by an impressive upstart -- the oral swab. Testing saliva increasingly looks to be faster, cheaper and less invasive than examining urine. But that doesn't mean that companies selling gear for saliva test are worthy investments. To the contrary, most of them are, well, spitting into the wind.   The problem is a firmly entrenched urine-test-only policy for some 11 million federal employees. Until that changes, saliva tests won't gain the credibility needed to take hold broadly. Though the Department of Health and Human Services has been mulling a change in this rule for more than two years, no resolution in sight. One federal workers' union   opposes swabs, contending that bosses could administer the test and produce "false positives."   Result: The stock prices of spit-dependent companies aren't likely to rise anytime soon. In fact, this intriguing sector is a case study of how regulation, rather than economics and practicality, can determine a product's success.   Drug testing, of course, isn't just for the Barry Bondses of the world. Millions of American workers and job applicants now undergo drug tests each year. For most of these people, oral swabs are the most sensible approach: You don't need a lab, and tests take just five to 15 minutes on-site.   Indeed, companies promoting saliva tests can't stop talking up the benefits -- undeterred by the apparently immovable object known as the federal government.   One of these companies is American Bio Medica (ticker: ABMC) of Kinderhook, N.Y. It boasts that its on-site saliva test for illegal drugs is the most sensitive.   Founder and CEO Stan Cipkowski declares that several "strategic relationships" in the works will show "we are going right through the roof in 2007!"   Too bad investors aren't salivating: The stock has plunged to under $1 from $2 in 2005 and, as a result, faces possible Nasdaq delisting on Feb. 22, according to Cipkowski.   Avitar, of Canton, Mass., another distressed maker of oral swabs, has seen its shares (AVTI.OB) tumble from $17.50 in 2004 to three cents, on the over-the-counter bulletin board. Peter Cholakis, the company's vice president of marketing, partly blames lobbying by urine testers. "Urine-testing labs do not want to see other technologies take hold," he says.   Avitar estimates that employers spend $1.5 billion-per-year for drugs-of-abuse testing, primarily in pre-employment screening. But that may be wishful thinking: Competitor Medtox Scientific, a St. Paul, Minn., urine-testing company, says the total market is closer to $400 million.   Medtox, with a market value of about $100 million, began trading on Nasdaq in February 2006 and has started making money after some big losses. Its shares (MTOX), which climbed nearly 60% in the past year, to a recent $12, look like one of the better bets in the drug-testing world.   Though its price-earnings ratio may appear high -- at nearly 20 times estimated earnings for the next 12 months -- it could well be justified by earnings gains. Analysts expect earnings growth of about 20% a year over the next five years.   OraSure Technologies (OSUR) is one of the few substantial stocks that might benefit from a pickup in oral drug testing -- when and if that happens.   With a market value of $375 million, it already has done well with oral HIV testing. Though oral drug testing is now a tiny part of its business, OraSure's earnings definitely would get a boost if Health and Human Services were to approve swabs, says Ed Shenkan, an analyst with Needham & Co.   Shenkan rates the stock Hold, though he's more bullish for the long term because of the strength of the company's HIV product.   Frequent expectations that a federal policy favoring swabs is imminent have always turned out to be overly optimistic, Shenkan warns.   None of which keeps Cipkowski of embattled American Bio Medica from hoping. He asserts that swabs have a clear cost advantage. "Labs charge between $25 and $40 for a standard five-panel drug test and we charge $12 to $18 for saliva," he says.   And urine tests do have an Achilles' heel: They are easily defeated by employees using drug-free urine, in powder or liquid form, available from Internet merchants or other sources. The Government Accountability Office in 2005 found 400 drug-masking products online.   In some law-enforcement settings, suspects or parolees must be observed giving a sample -- so at least one company markets a prosthetic device resembling a you-know-what connected by tube to a plastic bag filled with "clean" urine that can be hidden down a pant leg. A television actor in 2006 was convicted of a parole violation after he admitted using this product.   All of which raises the strong possibility that Health and Human Services one day will approve oral swabs. Until then, however, caution is the watchword for investors. If if you jump onto the spit bandwagon too soon, you could take an ugly soaking.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 00:05 ET (05:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
