Headline: Barron's(2/12) Plugged In: Ackman Gains An Ally
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Mark Veverka   Hedge-fund manager Bill Ackman's hostile campaign to supplant the board at Ceridian and force the company to spin off its fast-growing Comdata subsidiary gained an ally last week when fellow activist investor Ralph Whitworth of Relational Investors joined forces in his proxy war.   In a letter, Whitworth told the company that Ceridian (ticker: CEN) "could benefit from fresh blood" and that he found it "flabbergasting that [Chief Executive Kathryn] Marinello chose not to reach out to shareholders" and win their support. In a story last week on Ceridian, Barron's reported on the potential upside to Comdata's lucrative prepaid gift-card technology.   Whitworth's letter is the latest salvo in the Ceridian drama, which began in December, when Ackman's Pershing Capital Management disclosed its 11.3% stake in the company.   What's interesting about Whitworth's "fresh blood" jibe -- although implicitly referring to the board -- is that Marinello has been on the job for only five months. Ackman seems to have taken aim on Marinello, an alumna of General Electric, after a January meeting between the two. In correspondence to Ceridian filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Ackman says he came away from the meeting with the understanding that Marinello "intends to retain Comdata as a captive subsidiary."   Her old boss wasn't surprised by his protege's tough stand. "Katie's got real courage. She's got a real edge and is a strong-willed woman," said former GE CEO Jack Welch in an interview.   In his letters to Ceridian, Ackman professed dismay at Marinello's lack of enthusiasm for his Comdata spinoff proposal and concern over what he perceives to be Marinello's hankering for a buyout binge at the expense of failing to address low margins in Ceridian's core corporate payroll business. What's more, Ackman suggests that Marinello won't consider a spinoff because it would trim Ceridian's market value, putting limits on her ability to buy other companies.   Marinello denied the accusation in a letter of her own. "We do not understand your stated concern that we are proposing to embark on an 'acquisition-driven conglomerate strategy,'" she said. While it would be bad business to rule them out entirely, "acquisitions are not our current focus, and we do not have plans to pursue acquisitions over the next year," Marinello told Ackman.   Ackman's other key public concern is that Marinello has never been a CEO and has little experience with payroll or human services.   "I don't buy that at all," said Welch. At GE, Marinello proved that she was not an empire builder but a strong operator, he recalled, stating that she was assigned some troubled business lines, such as the credit operations of the defunct Montgomery Ward, and turned them around. "If he wants a turnaround or he wants to improve margins, he's got somebody who can improve margins," Welch declared.   He admitted that the performances of former GE executives-turned-CEO have been a "mixed bag," acknowledging the fall of ex-Home Depot boss Robert Nardelli. But Welch pointed to Intuit's Steve Bennett, Amgen's Kevin Sharer and former Honeywell CEO Larry Bossidy as sterling examples. "She still has to prove that she can do this, but I would bet on her," Welch said of Marinello.   For now, Whitworth is betting on Ackman.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 00:03 ET (05:03 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: US Contractor Killed By US Forces Near Entrance To Air Base
Story: BAGHDAD (AP)--The U.S. military confirmed on Saturday that American forces at Camp Anaconda, the huge air base north of Baghdad, shot and killed a civilian contract truck driver.   A spokeswoman for KBR, a contracting subsidiary of Halliburton Co. (HAL) that was formerly known as Kellog, Brown & Root, said the incident was under investigation.   Spokeswoman Melissa Norcross said the company was not releasing the name of the dead driver or a second person in the truck who was wounded "to protect the individuals' privacy."   In Baghdad, Lt. Cmdr. Bill speaks said, "There was an escalation of force incident at Camp Anaconda on Feb. 5 (Monday) that resulted in the death of a civilian contractor. The incident is under investigation by the Army Criminal Investigation Division and KBR."   An escalation of force incident normally means a driver approaching a checkpoint didn't respond to military orders to approach slowly and stop.   "Sadly, 98 KBR employees and subcontractors have lost their lives, and more than 430 have been wounded by hostile action while performing services under the company's government contracts in Iraq, Afghanistan and Kuwait," Norcross said in an email response to queries about the incident, which was first reported on the Web site of a Flint, Michigan, television station.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 14:40 ET (19:40 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Poultry Sales Begin To Fall In UK - FT
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Consumers' fears over bird flu are beginning to bite, with J Sainsbury (SBRY.LN), U.K.'s third-largest supermarket chain, reporting a 10% fall in poultry sales over the past five days, the Financial Times reports Saturday, citing company sources.   The retailer, which last weekend said it hadn't seen any change in sales despite news that the H5N1 bird flu virus had been detected on a Suffolk farm of Bernard Matthews, said buying patterns were beginning to change, the paper reports.   It writes, Tesco (TSCO.LN) the U.K.'s largest retailer, said it had also seen a "slight dip." The paper adds that Tesco refused to comment on whether that trend had worsened over the course of the week.     Newspaper Web site: http://www.ft.com   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9320     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 06:16 ET (11:16 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Colombian Protesters Block Glencore's Coal Mine, 1 Dead
Story: BOGOTA (Dow Jones)--Clashes between a group of protesters blocking the Colombian coal mine of La Jagua owned by Swiss-based Glencore International AG and the police left one person dead on Saturday morning, according to a union leader.   People from the town of La Jagua Thursday started blocking access to the mine to protest against the pollution in the town, Joaquin Rivas, the president of the mine's labor union, told Dow Jones Newswires on Saturday.   He said protesters also demand the mine spend more on social works and to hire more people from the area.   "Right now, the mine is running at half its capacity and the production of coal is stranded at the mine," he added.   Glencore produces 2.5 million metric tons of coal per year at La Jagua mine.   On Saturday morning, the Colombian police intervened to scatter the protesters. One person died during the riots and 28 others were injured, the police reported, according to local radio RCN.   President Alvaro Uribe said he will travel to La Jagua on Sunday, the radio report added.   Protesters say the mine and the 1,200 trucks shipping coal out of the mine every day leave coal dust all over the town, causing lung disease and pollution.   The trailers also cause damage to the roads and traffic accidents. Recently, one such truck killed 20 people when it crashed with a small bus.   Jorge Carvajales, the Chief Executive of Glencore's Colombian unit, wasn't immediately available for comment.   Coal is Colombia's second-biggest export earner. In the first 11 months of 2006 the country exported $2.67 billion worth of coal.     -by Inti Landauro, Dow Jones Newswires; 57-1-600 19 80; colombia@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 17:18 ET (22:18 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/12) Follow-Up: A Subprime Lender's Woes Aren't Over
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jonathan R. Laing   The slow-motion train wreck in the U.S. subprime-mortgage market claimed another victim Thursday when shares of the major California-based specialist in the field, New Century Financial (ticker: NEW), tumbled 36% to 19.24. The company disclosed that it will report a loss for the fourth quarter of 2006, and will have to revise downward its financial results for the previous three quarters.   New Century, it seems, failed to reserve sufficiently for the flood of poorly performing mortgages it thought it had securitized and ousted from its books. Turns out trustees of securitized portfolios can force the original lender to take back bad paper if the homeowner defaults in the first six months of a loan's life. Also, New Century will have to write down the "residual" values of certain holdings it retained in its securitizations, because of a  jump in defaults and overly rosy valuation assumptions. The company warned that loan production this year could drop 20%.   Barron's readers were warned of New Century's impending problems over two years ago. ("No Margin of Safety," Oct. 11, 2004), when we highlighted a number of risks in its business model. The stock price was then 60. Subsequently, in "Coming Home to Roost" (Feb. 13, 2006), we argued that New Century, then at 38, was in the path of a likely tsunami of subprime-mortgage defaults.   The future seems anything but bright. The U.S. has yet to feel the full brunt of upward rate resets on the adjustable-rate mortgages of recent years, when underwriting standards slipped. Defaults should spiral higher as monthly payments surge. New Century relies on outside liquidity to finance the assembly of its mortgage pools, prior to their sale. And that financing depends on confidence, which recent events may shake.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 00:08 ET (05:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: =WSJ UPDATE: Lehman Bros Investment Banker Young Leaves Firm
Story: (Updates with comment from Lehman spokeswoman)     By Dennis K. Berman   Of THE WALL STREET JOURNAL     One of Lehman Bros. Holdings Inc.'s top investment bankers, Woody Young, has left the firm, according to people familiar with the matter.   As the focal point of Lehman's telecommunications practice, Mr. Young was in the thick of nearly every big telecom merger over the last decade.   (This story and related background material will be available on The Wall Street Journal Web site, WSJ.com.)   It was a fervent period of consolidation, and the deals helped Lehman push its merger advice business into the upper ranks of Wall Street, amid the likes of Morgan Stanley and Merrill Lynch.   The reasons for his departure remained unclear on Saturday, as is Mr. Young's next destination. On Friday, Mr. Young gathered colleagues and disclosed his departure, surprising many of them.   Notable banker moves have been relatively rare over the past few years, largely because a surging investment banking business have delivered sometimes-whopping pay packages to both senior and junior bankers.   "Woody Young has made valuable contributions to our investment banking franchise," a Lehman spokeswoman said Saturday. Mr. Young declined to comment Friday evening.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 13:55 ET (18:55 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Cadbury Recalls Some Of Its Easter Chocolates In UK, Ireland
Story: LONDON (AP)--Cadbury Schweppes PLC (CSG) is recalling some of its Easter eggs in the U.K. and Ireland because they have the wrong nut allergy labeling, the company said Saturday.   The recall affects selected products including "Mini Creme Eggs" and "Easter Chicks with Buttons," the company said. It planned to alert customers to the recall in advertisements to run Sunday.   People who have bought Easter eggs and chocolates on the recall list will be able to claim a full refund by writing to an address provided in the ad, the company said. Customers also can call a helpline, 44-800-818-181, or visit a company Web site: www.cadbury.co.uk/easterrecall.   Britain's Food Standards Agency said that Cadbury had informed it about the recall on Friday night, as required by law.   In June, Cadbury, which is based in Birmingham, was forced to withdraw seven confectionary products from the U.K.-Irish market after reporting salmonella contamination at a plant.   The Easter eggs are being recalled from the store shelves because they are unsafe for people with nut allergies and haven't been correctly labeled.   The products are still "perfectly safe" for those without a nut allergy, and no other Cadbury products are affected, Cadbury said in a statement.   It said the chocolate eggs "may contain traces of nuts. As a precaution, we advise nut allergy sufferers not to eat any of the Easter products until they either call the helpline number or log on to the Web site for further information."     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 05:05 ET (10:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/12) Speaking Of Dividends: Chew-Chew Train
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Shirley A. Lazo   What a difference a year makes.   When Wrigley (ticker: WWY) appeared in this space in February 2006 after sweetening its dividend, its fourth-quarter earnings had been gummed up by higher sugar prices and restructuring expenses. Last Tuesday, Wrigley again upped its payout, but this time it also reported a 37% jump in December-quarter profit, thanks to stronger sales, chiefly in Europe, Asia and the Middle East.   The Chicago-based king of the $15 billion globalchewing-gum market will now pay 29 cents a quarter on shares of its regular and Class B common, up 13% from 25.6 cents. Holders of record April 13 will receive the new disbursement May 1, and the stock goes ex-dividend April 11. Yield: 2.27%. Dividends have been paid without interruption since 1913 and enhanced every year since 1980.   Traded on the Big Board, the shares change hands not far below their 52-week high of 54.37, set Oct. 23. Standard & Poor's rates the stock a Strong Buy.   In 2006, Wrigley earned $529.4 million, or $1.90 a share, a 2% increase from 2005. Sales climbed 13%, to a record $4.5 billion. Despite big gains abroad, U.S. volume was flat, as declines in sales of sugared gum significantly offset advances by the sugar-free variety.   Wrigley is firing off a barrage of new products globally.   In challenging London-based Cadbury Schweppes, which is attempting to whittle down Wrigley's 98% share of the U.K. market, the company is launching two new gums, including one that will offer "enhanced dental benefits." In China, it will introduce a gum "featuring wellness benefits based on traditional Chinese medicine." Just in time for Valentine's Day, Wrigley has moved into the chocolate market by buying 80% of Russian premium chocolatier A. Korkunov, for $300 million. Four years ago, Wrigley unsuccessfully bid $12.5 billion for Hershey, which chose to stay independent.   Financial adviser Bryan Perry's passion is double-digit income investing. To that end and with over 20 years of experience on Wall Street, he launched an e-newsletter advisory service on Jan. 1, 2006, at ChangeWave Investing (www.changewave.com) called The 25% Cash Machine. He also has a book of the same name, published a month ago. Perry searches for securities that generate around 10% in income and at least 15% in capital gains annually.   Investors who follow his technique will own a basket of special-case, high-yield securities -- managing them from time to time as needed-to rotate among the economy's strongest sectors.   One of his favorite five for 2007 is Apollo Investment (AINV), a lender to midsize companies. Recently trading a bit above 23, it yields about 9% and is expected to boost revenue 33% this year. For a "Chindia" play (China plus India), he likes Diana Shipping (DSX). Priced at around 17 and yielding 9.45%, Diana is a way to leverage on the whole emerging-market theme surrounding the pan-Asian continent.   For a broad-market component, Perry favors the S&P 500 Covered Call Fund (BEP). With a 10.7% dividend yield, it returned 29% last year. Perry expects specialty finance to perform well; his top choice there is Deerfield Triarc Capital (DFR). This real-estate investment trust trades below 17, and is a 10% yielder. Perry believes convertible securities will beat most other assets in 2007. Here he likes Advent/Claymore Enhanced Growth & Income Fund (LCM), which is trading at a slight discount to its net asset value while producing a dividend yield exceeding 8%.   When Altria spins off its remaining stake in Kraft Foods (KFT) on March 30 (March 16 is the record date; April 2 is the ex-date), holders will receive 0.7 of a Kraft share for each Altria share. Altria (MO) will immediately adjust its dividend so that Altria investors who keep their Kraft stock will, in the aggregate, get the same annual payout they received before the transaction.   Post-spinoff Altria holders will get about $2.74 on their Altria shares and the equivalent of 70 cents for each Kraft share, thereby preserving the current $3.44 yearly dividend on Altria stock.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 00:04 ET (05:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/12) Follow-Up: Vonage Woes Show No Sign Of Ending
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Eric J. Savitz   For investors, the Vonage story has been tragic. Shares in the Internet telephony company (ticker: VG) have plummeted 65% to 5.38 from their May 2006 offering price of 17, and that slide includes a 22% selloff just since the start of '07.   If you're tempted to buy the stock now, don't. Vonage continues to add subscribers lured by its Internet phone service, which undercuts comparable service from the cable companies, but the company lacks the critical ability to offeranything like the triple-play packages of voice, video and data service now sold by both cable and phone concerns.   As a one-service company, Vonage could find itself crushed in the Titanic battle between the cable industry and the Bells for control of consumer-telecom dollars. As the battle intensifies, there is a risk the cable guys will chop the price they charge for phone service, undercutting Vonage's key weapon.   Barron's readers can't say they weren't warned of the company's woes and the likely course of its stock. I reviewed Vonage's situation three times, in each story sounding a cautionary note. In "Will Vonage Fly" (Oct. 31, 2005), which was published about six months before the IPO, I noted the company was looking to sell itself to the public or a private buyer, both potentially troubling courses.   A second piece, "Vonage's Wrong Numbers" (Feb. 13, 2006), scrutinized the company's IPO prospectus and warned that Vonage faced an uphill battle to reach profitability. In a Follow-Up last summer ("Weasel While You Work," July 10, 2006), I wrote that "the Vonage story gets uglier and uglier. And there's every reason to think it will get uglier still." And so it has.   In an interview with Barron's at the recent Consumer Electronics Show, Vonage CEO Jeff Citron noted that the company has produced double-digit growth for 18 quarters running. He also repeated his prediction that Vonage can turn "an adjusted operating profit" by the first quarter of 2008. Citron said the company expects to continue its heavy spending on advertising: an expected $360 million in 2006 and more than that this year. Vonage is shifting from edgy, male-oriented TV ads to a more diverse approach, reflecting a change in its customer base.   I'm as bearish as ever on Vonage. It is conceivable the stock has grown cheap enough to attract a private buyer, but I'm not sure why someone would bid. Vonage has a problematic business model: It is no more -- and no less -- than a supplier of plain, old phone service. With the cable companies and telcos blasting away at each other, wielding price as a weapon, Vonage could get caught in the crossfire.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 00:07 ET (05:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/12) Mind, As Much As Muscle, Sets Auction Prices
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Robert Campbell Rowe   As they approach their 60s, muscle-car collectors are finally starting to use their heads.   After driving the prices of virtually every big-engined brute from the 1960s and early '70s to record levels in recent years, baby boomers were much more discriminating at 2007's first big auto auctions held in and around Phoenix last month. They paid more than ever for limited-production models or those with unusual features, like the convertible 1971 Barracuda pictured above,but drew the line at ubiquitous hemi-powered Dodges and Plymouths, standard-issue Mustangs and Camaros with loads of street miles and less-than-complete restoration. (See accompanying illustration -- Barron's February 12)For the latter, prices were pretty much flat with those a year ago.   "Buyers have gotten very savvy," notes Steven Davis, president of Barrett-Jackson, which runs the biggest of the auctions, a carnival-like event reminiscent of a Nascar race that draws a quarter-million people, including 5,000 registered bidders. "There is a demand for verifiable quality," he says.   Adds Drew Alcazar, president of classic-car specialist Russo and Steele, which runs a four-day sale nearby, "The market has gotten conservative."   Of course, muscle cars aren't the only draw at these influential auctions. Vintage Ferraris, giant luxury cars like DeSotos from the '50s and Duesenbergs from the '30s, and even some rare pre-World War I Fords all received strong bids last month. Overall, the three auctioneers (another classic car purveyor, RM, also holds a sale near Phoenix) reported roughly $161 million in sales (1,670 cars), up slightly from 2006's $152 million (1,498), reflecting softening demand for lower-tier models.   Changes in the red-hot muscle-car market were most pronounced.   Consider some of the top sellers. Mustang Boss 429 Fastbacks from 1969 garnered anywhere from $253,000 for an "unmolested" (original, but not restored) model to $489,500 for a better-looking one to $605,500 for a perfectly presented specimen. Prices at the very top end were roughly twice what they were just a couple of years ago. Lower-tier Mustang prices, however, stabilized at about $10,000 to $12,000 after roughly tripling in the past decade, says Davis.   Even sought-after Shelbys are seeing gradations in pricing. Shelby's top-of-the-line Cobra, a fabled race car that could be modified for street use and whose total production totaled about 1,000, did well: A 1967 Cobra 427 S/C (semi-competition) Roadster sold at the RM auction for $1.43 million, the high end of its presale estimate. (A heavily promoted "Super Snake" Cobra, with 800 horsepower and owned by famed designer Carroll Shelby himself, took in an auction-leading $5.5 million.) But so-called Mustang Shelbys that Ford made in much greater numbers in the late 1960s fetched about $100,000 each for models in less-than-mint condition, a fraction of what their fully reconditioned siblings pulled down.   The same trend was evident in the 66 Camaros that Barrett-Jackson sold. A 1969 ZL1 coupe, a race car with an unusual 427-cubic-inch engine, sold for a remarkable $880,000 while two similar-vintage -- but much more common -- Z/28 RS coupes generated a combined $264,000.   Increasingly, buyers want proof that their purchases are what the sellers say they are. Records, starting with "build sheets" (factory paperwork), original bills of sale, matching serial numbers on major components and awards won at recognized car shows can all lift muscle-car values these days.     The buyers' newly discriminating taste runs in obvious contrast to the freewheeling image of muscle cars, which roared into American consciousness in the early 1960s with up to 400-plus horsepower. They were relatively cheap, great for drag racing on local streets and mythologized in countless songs, TV shows and movies. But they didn't do well on curves, especially with their target market -- young drivers -- at the wheel. By the late 1970s, safety concerns and rising fuel prices forced them off the road in favor of smaller, more energy-efficient and better-handling Japanese compacts.   By the 1990s, however, muscle-car collections were surging.  Even well-traveled models like the 1965 Mustang coupe began to attract bids of $3,500 or more from nostalgic middle-aged men. Their quick ascent in price has ruffled feathers among traditional car collectors. The editor of Sports Car Market magazine recently compared muscle cars' popularity to that of the Beanie Babies a decade ago, and predicted that prices were "about to fall off a cliff." Another writer for the magazine sniffed that the cars appealed "to the blue-collar crowd and many upwardly mobile construction workers-turned-contractors. . . . " His advice: "Sell your muscle cars, enjoy your Ferraris."   Instead of disappearing, it seems buyers' passions have become more refined. Owners of Dodges and Plymouths featuring hemis (hemispherical-combustion-chamber V8 engines created by Chrysler in 1951) were among those having to downshift their expectations in Phoenix. Prices for these models were flat, and some think they may be headed lower, because thousands are still around. Chrysler even puts modernized hemis in some new models.   As in other parts of the muscle-market, there are exceptions -- like the Plymouth Hemi 'Cuda convertibles -- that prove the rule. Last year, a 1970 Barracuda fetched an astounding $2.16 million at the Barrett-Jackson auction. Last month, a 1971 version garnered $2.42 million in the sale run by classic-car specialists RM, whose one-day auction is held at the tony Arizona Biltmore hotel. Only 11 of these 425-horsepower convertibles were originally sold (1971 was the last model year) and just two were delivered in the U.S.     Of course, many of the valuation methods now shaping muscle-car prices have been affecting collectible sports cars for years, especially high-end pre-1970 models. Ferrari tops this list. After a crazy speculative price bubble in 1989, when Japanese investors shelled out $10 million to $12 million for top Ferraris, prices nosedived, along with Japanese stocks. They've quietly come back, increasing by more than 50% in the past few years.   RM sold a 1957 Ferrari 250 Boano LWB (long wheelbase) Berlinetta for $720,000; a 1967 330 GTC went for $220,000. Rarity works in Ferraris' favor: Even the more common versions seldom numbered more than 1,000 to 1,200; others totaled less than 100. "Interest is very strong for vintage sports and racing cars," says Rob Myers, the founder of RM.   Certain types of "Land Yachts," or big luxury cars from the 1950s, also did very well in Phoenix. Their prices have risen more than 50% over the course of the past couple of auctions.   Convertibles were in particular demand. Barrett-Jackson sold a 1959 DeSoto Firesweep Convertible for $319,200 and a 1959 DeSoto Adventurer Convertible for $253,000. That's considered the best vintage for these flamboyant luxury cars, as Detroit's auto makers battled to "outfin" one another. Both DeSotos were professionally restored, original and rare. At RM, a 1956 Lincoln Premiere convertible, one of 2,447 made that year, fetched $181,500.   Big luxury cars from the 1930s are also climbing in value because of their scarcity and the limited possibility of a "barn find" (discovery of a previously unknown one). The ultimate American car of that era, Duesenberg, continued to gain luster. A Model SJ Cabriolet sold at RM's auction for $2.805 million. It's the last one ever made, and its body -- created in 1940, three years after the chassis --  was made by Rollson Coachbuilders, considered one of the greatest metal benders of its era.   As scarce as these DeSotos, Lincolns and Duesenbergs are, there are still far more of them around than the very oldest pre-World War I cars, known as "Brasses." RM sold a 1903 Ford Model-A Rear Entrance Tonneau for $693,000. It is the oldest surviving car built by Ford and has all the documentation to prove it. Bidders consider these cars the equivalent of extremely rare antiques.   Of course, not every car at the auctions sold for hundreds -- or even tens -- of thousands of dollars or deserved museum treatment. Some are made to be driven. A guy from Nebraska bought a 1980 Dodge pick-up at the auction for $4,700. Why?   "I needed a ride home," he said.   ---   ROBERT CAMPBELL ROWE, a long-time editor and publisher of magazines and books on collecting, is a freelance writer in Phoenix.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 00:09 ET (05:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/12) The Trader: A Late Selloff Trims The High Fliers
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Kopin Tan   Anyone who has ever been snowed in knows that the longer the confinement, the greater the desire to bust out and bolt. For six consecutive days, the Standard & Poor's 500 index had been trapped upon closing within a tight four-point range between 1446 and 1450, one of the narrowest in three decades. With each fitful session, the odds increased that the crowd would jump on the first sign of a breakout, no matter its cause.   Friday, a pair of speeches by Federal Reserveofficials warning of higher interest rates if inflation doesn't ebb gave investors a reason to pick a direction at last. That direction was south. That the Fed will lift borrowing costs if prices rise hardly is news. But with stocks perched at precarious peaks, it provided a tidy excuse for a tetchy crowd to take some profits.   Friday's selloff took down many of the market's recent high-fliers, from real estate investment trusts to hot stocks like MasterCard (ticker: MA) and Las Vegas Sands (LVS). The S&P 500 reached a 6 1/2-year high midweek but ended the week lower for the third time in four weeks, declining 10, or 0.7%, to 1438. The Dow Jones Industrials lost 73, or 0.6%, to 12,581.   The Nasdaq Composite also fell for the third time in four weeks, edging down 16, or 0.6%, to 2460. The Russell 2000 index of small stocks reached a record 816 Thursday, but Friday's drop took it down 2, or 0.3%, to 807 for the week. The bond market sold off, too.   While bargain hunters stepped in to stop the slide Friday afternoon, the reversal from stocks' midweek high will give bears a rare glimmer of hope. The Nasdaq's inability to ride the midweek lift from Cisco Systems' (CSCO) robust outlook also points to the increasingly conspicuous weakness in the technology sector. Bank stocks' retreat amid credit concerns will vex those looking to financials to lead.   But Friday's setback can hardly qualify as a surprise. Even bulls have come to expect this extended market to take a breather. As the broad Dow Jones Wilshire 5000 index pushed to a seven-year high Wednesday, put buying and hedging generally kept pace with bullish call buying. A mere four stocks slipped to 52-week lows at the Big Board midweek, and while that number is likely to tick up, the market's strength remains largely intact. But amid the growing uncertainties, gold rose to $667.50 an ounce, an eight-month high.   So, is this a pause that might refresh, or the start of a deeper pullback? For a market fixated on monetary policy, much will depend on the economic assessment offered by Fed chairman Ben Bernanke when he testifies before Congress this week. Recent economic data have been benign, corroborating the view of a soft economic landing, although that may be substantially factored into stock prices.   What else is on Carl Icahn's shopping list? That question has been making the rounds since the billionaire investor announced he had amassed a 1.4% stake in Motorola (MOT), and plans to prod the company to buy back a very big pile of its cheap shares.   If Icahn's assessment is right, other telecom-equipment and chip companies may soon find themselves caught in the cross-hairs of impatient shareholders or buyout firms, all eyeing their cash stashes. And Icahn isn't the only one on the prowl. Recent multi-billion buyouts of Freescale Semiconductor (FSL) and Philips Electronics' (PHG) chip unit suggest that cash-rich chip or telecom-equipment makers with underleveraged balance sheets are quickly becoming a new quarry.   "Both events represent an effort to extract shareholder value through a change in capital structure," says Zhiping Zhao, a senior analyst at the independent research firm CreditSights, who sees mounting "pressure from shareholders for these companies to return excess cash, as well as optimize capital structure and create shareholder value."   For management, this is a relatively new threat exacerbated by maturing businesses, slowing growth and increasingly conspicuous piles of cash. According to CreditSights, cash makes up roughly 19.1% of the total market cap of semiconductor makers, compared with 6.1% for consumer cyclicals, 5.8% for materials and 4.9% for industrial companies. Chip and telecom-equipment companies also have little or no debt, and relatively limited stock-buyback and dividend plans.   For much of the past decade, investors have looked to these companies to deliver accelerating growth, with cash understandably earmarked for funding expansion or acquisitions. But the buying frenzy and capital expenditures have cooled since the tech heyday, and pressure is coming to bear to optimize the balance sheet, especially for companies that have failed to appease investors by improving stock returns.   Sure, the ability to wring operating- profit improvements or cut cost will vary widely in these sectors, and chip companies' historically muted multiples must be viewed against some of these companies' uncertain growth prospects. But Zhao flagged companies like ADI (ADI), Linear Technologies (LLTC), Maxim (MXIM), Altera (ALTR), and Xilinx (XLNX) as potential LBO targets. European companies like Infineon (IFX) and ST Microelectronics also screen as cheap LBO targets considering the debt that can be loaded onto their ledgers.   If telecom-equipment companies' fluctuating cash flow gives buyout investors pause, heavyweights like Motorola, Ericsson (ERIC), and Nokia (NOK) that have under-leveraged balance sheets could face shareholder pressure to unlock value. So too could fallen angels like Sycamore Networks (SCMR), and smaller equipment vendors like Tellabs (TLAB).     Home builders' stocks have found firmer ground since the summer, but disheartening news last week threatened to rattle that fragile foundation. The case for the home builders months ago was built on attractive price-to-book valuations, solid balance sheets and conviction that a downturn in the housing market was factored amply into the group's slip-sliding shares. But a 33% surge in the S&P Homebuilders SPDR Fund (XHB) since mid-July, double the broad market's robust advance, made the group vulnerable to a pullback in the absence of better profits.   Things got wobbly last week after luxury home builder Toll Brothers (TOL) announced a 33% drop in orders and warned investors to expect larger write-downs when it reports earnings later this month. Rising delinquencies and soured loans at HSBC Holdings (HBC) and New Century Financial (NEW) added to the unease (see story on page 20). Was that a preview of coming distractions?   Home-building stocks tend to rise in tandem with Treauries, as bond-market rallies and corresponding declines in yields and interest rates help bolster home demand. Yet, the home builders have marched higher, even with yields up since December and strong economic data extending an anticipated rate cut further into the future, notes Michael Benhamou, a London-based managing partner at Louis Capital Markets.   With the sector now trading at about 20 times forward earnings, ahead of the 15 times for the broad market, Benhamou reckons there's downside risk of about 25%. A bearish bet on the XHB paired with a bullish one using the S&P depositary receipts (SPY) allows one to benefit from the sector's relative underperformance in the short term.   While there are early signs that the rise in buyers bailing has started to slow, cancellations are 34% higher than last year, and rising mortgage defaults and foreclosures threaten to add to the inventory glut. Construction normally slated for spring also might have occured in December and January amid balmy weather, which the cold front has now put in the deep freeze.   More important, aggressive reliance by home builders on incentives, land-related write-downs and price discounts to goose sales could exact a toll on 2007 margins and profits, as well as recent stock gains. With capital flowing into the sector ETF, Tom McManus, Banc of America Securities' chief U.S. strategist, cautions that "the housing recovery will be slow, a drawn out process."   Home builders might have suffered their biggest losses. But investors betting on a rebound often are early. Expect restoration --  like any home renovation -- to go over schedule and test patience.   ---                       VITAL SIGNS                                Friday's     Week's     Week's                                 Close     Change     % Chg. Headline: Barron's(2/12) European Trader: HSBC Pays The Price
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Martin Fluck, Arindam Nag and Matthew Curtin   HSBC is paying the price for winning market share in the U.S. at any price. But what's more worrying for investors is what HSBC's problems say about the outlook for other U.S. mortgage lenders and the prospects for American economic growth if defaults on home loans worsen.   In the States, HSBC (HBC) offers nonstandard products like interest-only mortgages, and it has been an aggressive player in the second-lien market since 2003 when it bought U.S. mortgage group Household Finance, many of whose customers' homes have wheels. In addition, HSBC North America is far less focused on the liability side of a balance sheet than, say, Royal Bank of       HSBC North America had half as many customer deposits -- $147 billion -- as customer loans -- $288 billion -- at the end of 2006.   Despite this imbalance, HSBC's North American mortgage lending business accounted for only 5% or so of its parent company's total profit in 2006. And while HSBC raised its troubled-loan provisions for 2006-2008 by 20% more than the average of analysts' forecasts, some had expected even worse news. Dresdner Kleinwort, for example, had looked for a 50% rise. That may explain why HSBC's shares fell only 2% Thursday.   By coming clean on the extent of its potential bad-debt problem, HSBC's action does suggest that heavy provisioning is coming at other banks exposed to the U.S. home-loan market. Not only that, but bad debts may be spreading beyond the higher-risk segment.   Sub-prime mortgage lending is a leading indicator for the rest of the economy, and delinquency trends are accelerating. For investors, this raises the specter of a slow-motion crash for the American economy, even though many are confident that growth will hold up through 2007 amid signs housing prices have bottomed.   Rising U.S. bond yields in January should feed through to more costly mortgages -- keeping the housing market under pressure. And recent Fed surveys suggest that mortgage lenders are tightening lending standards.   All this indicates that investors in U.S. banking stocks can expect another round of asset impairments. After all, it's human nature to try to manage your debt burden as long as possible before biting the bullet.     BHP Billiton's massive share buyback program reflects the miner's confidence in its future internal growth and pricing power.   That confidence is unshaken, despite the acquisition sprees of many of its rivals and consolidation among its most important consumers, as well as China's emergence as a net exporter of raw materials. The $10 billion buyback, on top of a 14% dividend hike, to be implemented through 2008 shows that BHP believes it can generate large amounts of operating cash flow.   Management seems confident that it can handle the bumps of incremental labor and other capital costs,too. By the time the latest planned buyback ends, BHP Billiton will have returned nearly $27 billion to investors since mid-2001, despite having spent $7 billion to buy Australian miner WMC Resources in 2003 to boost its nickel portfolio   Overall, BHP (ticker: BBL) believes that finding projects on its own is more lucrative than spending money on acquisitions. That contrasts with the strategy of many of its rivals. Last year, more than $126.6 billion was spent on 1,022 M&A deals in the mining sector, according to the DealLogic research firm.   That said, BHP isn't losing out on investment opportunities. The company has a $17 billion pipeline of projects including two U.S. oil & gas projects that will cost $3.5 billion and two ventures in western Australia: the $2.2 billion Ravensthorpe nickel project and a $1.3 billion iron-ore project.   Even if costs jump, as they have already done at Ravensthorpe, BHP's cash flow can absorb it. Its capex is roughly 40% of its operating cash flow. And should a major acquisition beckon, BHP would have little problem funding one. Its net debt, at a little under $8 billion, equals 25% of its total capital.   Even if it borrowed another $10 billion, it could continue with the share-buyback program without over-stretching its credit rating. And there are at least a dozen miners currently valued under $10 billion, including Vedanta Resources (VED.U.K.) Lonmin and Antofagasta (ANTO.U.K).   That said, the deluge of cash on the miners' books has been noticed by steel makers, particularly as the consolidation of that industry has begun in earnest.   More consolidation may be necessary for the steel producers' bargaining power to improve significantly. But Chinese steel makers -- led by Baosteel -- have reportedly been taking a tough stance in negotiations over iron-ore contracts. The recent 9.5% rise in prices, which takes effect in April, might not be repeated again soon.   And demand for raw materials may yet slacken if China's government successfully applies the brake to its booming economy. Base metal prices have fallen abruptly in recent weeks.   Still, these are good days for BHP's investors. And its willingness to line its shareholders' pockets may pressure rivals Rio Tinto (RTP) and Anglo American (AAUK) to become more generous.     After Alcatel-Lucent tumbled to a fourth-quarter loss, its outlook for 2007 hardly inspires unbridled optimism.   Yet CEO Patricia Russo contends that the telecom-equipment supplier will grow in line with the sector this year, even though revenue will shrink, at least in the first quarter. To meet her projection, the company would have to grab market share in the final nine months of the year. That would be a tall order for a company in the throes of a difficult merger.   The extra 12,500 job cuts that Alcatel-Lucent envisions are hardly likely to help staff morale, even if they have whetted investors' appetite for a medium-term improvement in margins.   Alcatel-Lucent's American depositary shares, which closed Monday at 12.75, ended Thursday at 13.67 on optimism about the headcount reduction. But they slumped Friday on the realization that trimming the company's payroll could be difficult, given union threats to strike in protest, and France's coming presidential and parliamentary elections.   Socialist Party candidate Segolene Royal, whose rhetoric took a leftward lurch last week, is only a few points behind conservative rival Nicolas Sarkozy in the polls.   Alcatel-Lucent Chairman Serge Tchuruk has said in the past that cutting jobs in France isn't any more difficult than in any other developed country; it just takes six months longer. Even if he's right, that's time that Alcatel-Lucent can ill afford.   Commercially, Alcatel-Lucent faces the challenge of rationalizing its portfolio of Alcatel, Lucent, Fujitsu and Nortel gear.   As Alcatel-Lucent also found in the fourth quarter, competition remains tough in the telecom-equipment sector. Renewed buying by U.S. telephone companies will help only to a degree in the coming months.   L.M. Ericsson's belief that the overall market won't grow as fast in 2007 as it thought is hardly reassuring for Alcatel-Lucent. After all, Ericsson (ERIC) seems to be the mainstream supplier that's gaining share.   Alcatel-Lucent is likely to miss its revenue and earnings targets this year, while incurring heavy restructuring costs. In the short term, it also faces the unpleasant prospect of squeezed cash flow and, possibly, a strained balance sheet.   At a price that works out to around 18 times estimated 2007 earnings, Alcatel-Lucent's shares don't look attractive for the risk-averse.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 00:09 ET (05:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Max Re Capital Ltd. Announces Dividend
Story: HAMILTON, Bermuda--(BUSINESS WIRE)--February 10, 2007--   Max Re Capital Ltd. (NASDAQ: MXRE; BSX: MXRE BH) announced today that the Company's Board of Directors, at a meeting held on February 9, 2007, declared a quarterly dividend of $0.07 per share.     The dividend is payable on March 9, 2007, to shareholders of record as of February 23, 2007.     Max Re Capital Ltd., through its principal operating subsidiaries, Max Re Ltd., Max Insurance Europe Limited and Max Re Europe Limited, provides insurance and reinsurance products to corporations, public entities, property and casualty insurers, and life and health insurers.     This release includes statements about the Company's future expectations, plans and prospects that constitute forward-looking statements for purposes of the safe harbor provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Such forward-looking statements are subject to certain risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those suggested by such statements, including the risk that the SEC's view of the conclusions reached by the Audit and Risk Management Committee of the Company's Board of Directors in connection with the internal review of three finite risk retrocessional contracts written in 2001 and 2003, which caused the Company to restate its audited financial statements for the years ended December 31, 2005, 2004, 2003, 2002 and 2001 and unaudited financial statements for the periods ended March 31, 2006, and June 30, 2006, may differ, perhaps materially, and result in material changes to information contained in the Company's past SEC filings, including financial statements and financial information. Headline: 2ND UPDATE: Nasdaq's London Stock Exchange Bid Fails
Story: (Updates with additional comments, background throughout)     By Gaston F. Ceron   OF DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--Nasdaq Stock Market Inc.'s (NDAQ) latest effort to buy the London Stock Exchange PLC (LSE.LN) failed, raising questions as to where either exchange goes from here while other markets such as the New York Stock Exchange continue to expand.   Nasdaq's offer to buy out the LSE's investors attracted weak support, garnering less than one percent of the LSE's ordinary shares, Nasdaq said Saturday, as investors weren't inspired by Nasdaq's bid, which valued the LSE below where its shares have been trading.   In the short term, Nasdaq's failure is a victory for LSE management, especially Chief Executive Clara Furse, who has resisted Nasdaq's takeover efforts since last year, when Nasdaq approached the LSE about a merger. It's also a defeat for Nasdaq Chief Executive Robert Greifeld, who spent much energy and hundreds of millions of dollars in trying to capture the elusive LSE.   The future for both markets is unclear. Without a merger partner, the LSE and Nasdaq are, at least for now, left out as other exchanges consolidate. For example, the Big Board, a unit of NYSE Group Inc. (NYX), has had a considerably easier time expanding overseas. NYSE Group is soon expected to complete its takeover of Euronext NV (29064.AE), a pan-European stocks and derivatives exchange, and also has agreed to buy a stake in India's National Stock Exchange and to set up an alliance with the Tokyo Stock Exchange.   In a statement, Greifeld said he was disappointed with the outcome of the LSE offer and that Nasdaq will continue to pursue other opportunities. Nasdaq didn't say explicitly what it will do with its LSE stake now, but said that as the British exchange's largest investor it will monitor how its business performs in the future. A person familiar with the matter said Nasdaq likes having the LSE stake, but that it will keep all options open.   "My sense is that they'll likely look to hold on to the stake," said Richard Herr, an analyst at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods. Keefe, Bruyette & Woods has investment-banking ties to Nasdaq, but Herr doesn't own Nasdaq shares.   Another question is whether Nasdaq will now seek to do a deal with another exchange. The person familiar with the matter said Nasdaq is keeping the door open to such a move. For exchanges, mergers are seen as providing potential benefits such as opportunities to cut expenses, link markets and expand into other products. "I don't think they can just sit on the sidelines," said Herr, referring to Nasdaq.   The analyst said a U.S. options exchange may be an alluring merger partner for Nasdaq, although there could be other options. Nasdaq spokeswoman Bethany Sherman declined to comment on whether Nasdaq, which is planning to launch its own options market, would be interested in buying an existing options exchange. Meanwhile, in the U.S., Nasdaq is continuing its battle for trading market share and company stock listings with the NYSE.   Nasdaq said the results of its offer yielded only an additional 0.41% of the LSE's ordinary shares by the time it expired Saturday. Together with Nasdaq's previous 28.75% stake, this means Nasdaq owns or has received acceptances for shares representing about 29.16% of the LSE. "As the final offers have now lapsed, LSE shareholders have ceased to be bound by any such acceptances," Nasdaq said in a statement.   Nasdaq's offer to buy LSE shares at 1,243 pence apiece was below where the market has been valuing LSE shares, complicating the U.S. electronic exchange's efforts to woo LSE investors. Friday, LSE shares traded at 1,282 pence, while Nasdaq shares rose 99 cents, or 2.7%, to $37.20.   "We are naturally disappointed at this outcome as we remain of the view that the final offers represented a full and fair price for LSE shareholders. However, this disappointment is tempered by the knowledge that we remained true to our value case. We have a highly disciplined approach to acquisitions and will only consummate transactions to the extent that they deliver clear and visible benefits for Nasdaq shareholders, and enable us to allocate benefits to market participants," said Nasdaq CEO Greifeld, in a statement.   "Nasdaq will continue to pursue other opportunities to build on its existing position as the world's largest electronic equities exchange and we look forward to maintaining our strong track record of creating shareholder value through our industry leading business model and strategy," Greifeld added.   Nasdaq's quest to buy the LSE became public in March 2006, when Nasdaq unveiled a takeover proposal that was rejected by the U.K. exchange. Since then, Nasdaq built up a large stake in LSE shares, offered to buy more shares from LSE investors and traded barbs with LSE management, which has resisted Nasdaq's efforts throughout.   Minutes after Nasdaq's Saturday announcement, the London Stock Exchange responded.   "The board of the London Stock Exchange welcomes the rejection by shareholders of Nasdaq's offer. The exchange looks forward to fulfilling its vision to be the world's capital market, without the distraction of ill-considered approaches which fail to understand the value of the business," the LSE's statement said.   "The exchange's strategy has produced outstanding results for shareholders by facilitating a structural shift in volume growth in an increasingly international market at the center of the world's equity flows," LSE Chairman Chris Gibson-Smith said in the statement. "The exchange intends to build on its exceptionally valuable brand by progressing various competitive, collaborative and strategic opportunities, thereby reinforcing its uniquely powerful position in a fast evolving global sector."     -By Gaston F. Ceron, Dow Jones Newswires; 201-938-5234; gaston.ceron@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 13:53 ET (18:53 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/12) Research Reports: How Analysts Size Up Companies
Story: (From BARRON'S)     Edited By Anita Peltonen   The research reports excerpted here were issued recently by investment firms. Many may be obtained through Thomson Financial at www.thomson.com/financial or 800-638-8241. Some are available in the company-research area of WSJ.com, or through Factiva.com. Some of the reports' issuers have provided, or hope to provide, investment-banking or other services to the companies being analyzed.     Cognizant Technology Solutions   -- CTSH-NNM     Buy   -- Price 92.95 on Feb. 6   by Gilford Securities     2006 earnings per share reach $1.55, versus $1.30 outlook on 61% year-over-year revenue growth. Reaffirming [Buy] on basis of industry-leading 37% compound EPS growth in estimated 2006-'08-[and] outstanding execution record and margin cushion . . . we are raising our estimates as follows: 2007 GAAP diluted EPS to $2.20 on revenue of $2.127 billion (49% y-o-y growth) from $2 on revenue of $2.041 billion. . . . Increasing 12-month target from $85 to $109 . . . correspond[ing] to 35-40 times forward GAAP diluted EPS of $2.90 [versus] a current 42 times. . . . Cognizant is the fourth-largest software exporter from India.     DealerTrack Holdings   -- TRAK-NNM     Strong Buy   -- Price 28.26 on Feb. 6   by JMP Securities     DealerTrack has . . . an entrenched network that connects [auto] dealers to lending sources . . . While there may be quarter-to-quarter volatility in transaction volumes and subscription mix . . . the primary drivers of 25%+ earnings growth remain a long runway of lender growth . . . [alongside] adoption of eContracting and other workflow tools. Our 33 target is based on roughly 25 times implied '08 earnings, assuming mid-20% growth . . . [that could approach] 30 times as EPS grows annually.     Delia's   -- DLIA-NNM     Buy   -- Price 10.66 on Feb. 6   by Maxim Group     Delia's offers . . . skateboard [and] snowboard-related apparel and merchandise to [teenagers via] 74 mall-based stores and [various] catalogs and Websites. Initiating with Buy and 13 price objective, derived by applying a 30 times P/E multiple to our fully taxed 2008 EPS estimate of 39 cents (60 cents using the lower tax rate that would utilize the company's $40 million [net operating loss]) and based on a fully diluted 34 million shares. We believe this high P/E multiple is warranted given our estimated 40% EPS growth in 2008.     Humana   -- HUM-NYSE     Underweight   -- Price 57.84 on Feb. 6   by Prudential Securities     Humana reported 4Q06 earnings of 92 cents per diluted share, 4 cents above consensus and 7 cents above our estimate. With 2 cents from venture-capital investments and solid earnings in Medicare businesses, HUM continues executing Medicare-focused growth plan. 4Q06 [brought] explosive growth. . . . HUM reported that about 46,000 Part D members switched to Medicare Advantage and [a somewhat underwhelming] 50,000 more should switch by March 31 . . . Raising '07 estimates to $3.85 from $3.35 [on] solid existing business and visibility. Target: 52.     Inergy   -- NRGP-NNM     Hold/Aggressive   -- Price 40.68 on Feb. 6   by A.G. Edwards     Prior fair-value estimate of 40 has been attained. . . . Our fundamental outlook for [this oil-and-gas storage/transport firm] remains positive, yet we believe [most] risk/reward potential's factored in. . . . Our FY07 [discounted cash flow] estimate of $1.70 per unit implies a price to DCF multiple of 24 times, a premium valuation. Distributions are still estimated to grow 37% in FY07, 35% in FY08.     United Community Banks   -- UCBI-NNM     Hold   -- Price 33.06 on Feb. 6   by Cohen & Co.     UCBI said it had reached an agreement to acquire Gwinnett Commercial Group, a commercial-banking organization with $675 million in total assets . . . [the deal should close in] 2Q07. According to SNL Financial, the aggregate transaction value at announcement was $220.1 million, or 20.2 times earnings, 340% of equity and tangible equity, and core-deposit premium of 36.3%, [versus] median deal ratios for [recent] southeast bank acquisitions . . . [of] 23.5 times earnings, 272% of tangible book and [CDP of] 24.9%. Deal will [boost] UCBI presence in metro Atlanta . . . raising target by $1 to 35 based on blended values derived via our discounted dividend model and application of an 18 times multiple to our '07 estimate.     Vimicro International   -- VIMC-NNM     Hold   -- Price 8.10 on Feb. 7   by Needham & Co.     Downgrading VIMC [China's first publicly traded fabless integrated-circuit design house] to Hold from Buy following company 1Q07 guidance significantly below estimates. We [see] the stock likely to trade between $6 (or approximately 2 times net cash per share) and $10 (15 times our 2008 non-GAAP EPS estimate), until VIMC reverses current gross-margin trends . . . Management blamed shortfall on seasonal factors around Chinese New Year and delayed Vista launch. But we believe . . . market-share loss to Taiwanese competitors . . . [was a factor].   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 00:06 ET (05:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Conflicts Of Interest Force Lovells Replacement - FT
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--The office of Clare Spottiswoode, who is representing policyholders in Aviva's moves to unlock GBP3 billion of surplus assets in the insurers life funds, has severed its relationship with law firm Lovells, because of concerns over potential conflicts of interest, the Financial Times reports Saturday.   Lovells is a long-standing adviser to Aviva's rival Prudential, which is stepping up efforts to unlock GBP9 billion of surplus assets, the paper writes.   The paper reports Spottiswoode's office said: "Issues of potential conflicts of interest have arisen recently which has resulted in the ending of Lovells retainer with us."   Newspaper Web site: http://www.ft.com   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9320     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 10, 2007 06:22 ET (11:22 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : NASDAQ Says Offer To Buy LSE Shares Expires
Story: NEW YORK, Feb. 10, 2007 (PRIME NEWSWIRE) -- The Board of The Nasdaq Stock Market, Inc. ("NASDAQ") announces that its Final Offers for London Stock Exchange Group plc ("LSE") have lapsed.   As at the date of this announcement Nightingale Acquisition Limited ("NAL"), a wholly owned subsidiary of NASDAQ, owns 61,291,389 LSE Ordinary Shares, representing approximately 28.75 per cent. of the existing issued ordinary share capital of LSE.   As at 1 p.m. today (London time) on Saturday 10 February 2007, being the final closing date, valid acceptances had been received by NAL in respect of a total of 880,144 LSE Ordinary Shares, representing approximately 0.41 per cent. of the existing issued ordinary share capital of LSE, and valid acceptances had been received by NAL in respect of a total of 34,541 LSE B Shares, representing approximately 0.44 per cent. of the existing issued B share capital of LSE.   Accordingly NAL owns, or has received valid acceptances in respect of, a total of 62,171,533 LSE Ordinary Shares representing approximately 29.16 per cent. of the existing issued ordinary share capital of LSE. As the Final Offers have now lapsed, LSE Shareholders have ceased to be bound by any such acceptances.   Save as disclosed in the Offer Document and above, neither NAL, NASDAQ nor so, as far as NAL and NASDAQ are aware, any person acting in concert with either of them, is interested in, or has any rights to subscribe for, any LSE Shares, nor does any such person have any short position or any arrangement in relation to LSE Shares *.   As can be seen from the transaction documentation, NASDAQ and LSE clearly have a significant difference of view on the prospective future performance of the LSE business.  We continue to believe that 1,243 pence in cash represents a full and fair price.  This view has been arrived at following careful consideration of the challenges facing the LSE business model going forward.   In our opinion, the London equity trading market is facing unprecedented change with the introduction of MiFID.  NASDAQ's experience of growing volume in a competitive environment suggests that yield pressure could be intense.  This in turn will impact upon LSE's future financial performance and hence its value case.   The accuracy or inaccuracy of LSE's projections can only be proven through the passage of time and NASDAQ, as LSE's largest shareholder, will monitor with interest how the business performs going forward.   NASDAQ President and CEO Robert Greifeld said:   "We are naturally disappointed at this outcome as we remain of the view that the Final Offers represented a full and fair price for LSE shareholders.  However, this disappointment is tempered by the knowledge that we remained true to our value case.  We have a highly disciplined approach to acquisitions and will only consummate transactions to the extent that they deliver clear and visible benefits for NASDAQ shareholders, and enable us to allocate benefits to market participants.   NASDAQ will continue to pursue other opportunities to build on its existing position as the world's largest electronic equities exchange and we look forward to maintaining our strong track record of creating shareholder value through our industry leading business model and strategy." urther information   ave as defined above, capitalised terms used in this announcement have the same meaning as in the Offer Document dated 12 December 2006, the First Response Document dated 8 January 2007 and the Second Response Document dated 23 January 2007.   * For these purposes: "arrangement" includes any agreement to sell or any delivery obligation or right to require another person to purchase or take delivery and borrowing and lending of LSE Shares.  An "arrangement" also includes any indemnity or option arrangement, any agreement or any understanding, formal or informal, of whatever nature, relating to LSE Shares which may be an inducement to deal or refrain from dealing in such securities; and "interest" includes any long economic exposure, whether conditional or absolute, to changes in the price of securities and a person is treated as having an "interest" by virtue of the ownership or control of securities, or by virtue of any option in respect of, or derivative referenced to, securities.   ENQUIRIES   he Nasdaq Stock Market, Inc.
